0.text:
IPC Section 1: Title and extent of operation of the Code

Description: This section provides the title of the legislation, namely the Indian Penal Code, and states that it extends to the whole of India except the state of Jammu and Kashmir.

Example Use Cases: The Code is applicable in all states and union territories of India for crimes committed within their jurisdiction.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a declaratory section defining the Code's applicability.
0.title: IPC Section 1: Title and extent of operation of the Code

1.text:
IPC Section 2: Punishment of offences committed within India

Description: Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Code for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he is guilty within India.

Example Use Cases: A foreign tourist committing theft in Delhi is subject to punishment under the IPC.

Punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.
1.title: IPC Section 2: Punishment of offences committed within India

2.text:
IPC Section 3: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within India

Description: Any person who, beyond India, commits an offence targeting a computer resource located in India, can be tried and punished under the IPC.

Example Use Cases: A person located in a foreign country hacks into a server located in Mumbai.

Punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.
2.title: IPC Section 3: Punishment of offences committed beyond, but which by law may be tried within India

3.text:
IPC Section 4: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences

Description: The provisions of this Code apply to any offence committed by any citizen in any place without and beyond India, or by any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India.

Example Use Cases: An Indian citizen commits murder in the United States; they can be tried under the IPC in India.

Punishment: Punishment as prescribed for the specific offence committed.
3.title: IPC Section 4: Extension of Code to extra-territorial offences

4.text:
IPC Section 5: Certain laws not to be affected by this Code

Description: This Code does not affect any special or local law, or any special jurisdiction or power conferred, or any special form of procedure prescribed, by any other law.

Example Use Cases: A case under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act (NDPS Act) will be governed by that special law, not the general provisions of the IPC.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it clarifies the application of special laws over the IPC.
4.title: IPC Section 5: Certain laws not to be affected by this Code

5.text:
IPC Section 6: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions

Description: Every definition of an offence and every penal provision in this Code shall be understood subject to the exceptions contained in the Chapter entitled "General Exceptions".

Example Use Cases: The definition of murder is subject to exceptions like private defence. If a killing is done in self-defence, it is not murder.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.
5.title: IPC Section 6: Definitions in the Code to be understood subject to exceptions

6.text:
IPC Section 7: Sense of expression once explained

Description: Every expression which is explained in any part of this Code is used in every part of this Code in conformity with the explanation.

Example Use Cases: The word "voluntarily" defined in Section 39 must be interpreted with that meaning wherever it appears in the Code.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.
6.title: IPC Section 7: Sense of expression once explained

7.text:
IPC Section 8: Gender

Description: The pronoun "he" and its derivatives are used for any person, whether male or female.

Example Use Cases: A woman can be charged with and convicted of an offence that uses the word "he", such as theft or murder.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.
7.title: IPC Section 8: Gender

8.text:
IPC Section 9: Number

Description: Unless the context indicates otherwise, words in the singular include the plural, and words in the plural include the singular.

Example Use Cases: The phrase "the offender" in a section can apply to one or multiple offenders.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.
8.title: IPC Section 9: Number

9.text:
IPC Section 10: Man

Description:  """Woman""

Example Use Cases: The word "man" denotes a male human being of any age, and the word "woman" denotes a female human being of any age.

Punishment: A 17-year-old male can be referred to as a "man" for the purposes of the IPC.
9.title: IPC Section 10: Man

10.text:
IPC Section 11: Person

Description: The word "person" includes any Company or Association or body of persons, whether incorporated or not.

Example Use Cases: A company can be prosecuted for an offence requiring a specific intent, like cheating or fraud.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
10.title: IPC Section 11: Person

11.text:
IPC Section 12: Public

Description: The word "public" includes any class of the public or any community.

Example Use Cases: An act done in a housing society common area can be considered an act done "in public".

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
11.title: IPC Section 12: Public

12.text:
IPC Section 13: Queen

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
12.title: IPC Section 13: Queen

13.text:
IPC Section 14: Servant of Government

Description: The words "servant of Government" denote any officer or servant continued, appointed or employed in India by or under the authority of the Government.

Example Use Cases: A clerk in a government office, a public school teacher, or a police constable is a servant of the Government.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
13.title: IPC Section 14: Servant of Government

14.text:
IPC Section 15: British India

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
14.title: IPC Section 15: British India

15.text:
IPC Section 16: Government of India

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
15.title: IPC Section 16: Government of India

16.text:
IPC Section 17: Government

Description: The word "Government" denotes the Central Government or the Government of a State.

Example Use Cases: An offence against the Government of Maharashtra is an offence against a State Government.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
16.title: IPC Section 17: Government

17.text:
IPC Section 18: India

Description: "India" means the territory of India excluding the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

Example Use Cases: An offence committed in the state of Tamil Nadu is committed within "India" as per the IPC.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
17.title: IPC Section 18: India

18.text:
IPC Section 19: Judge

Description: The word "Judge" denotes not only every person who is officially designated as a Judge but also every person who is empowered by law to give a definitive judgment in any legal proceeding.

Example Use Cases: A Magistrate presiding over a trial, a Sessions Judge, or even an arbitrator empowered by law to give a final judgment is a Judge.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
18.title: IPC Section 19: Judge

19.text:
IPC Section 20: Court of Justice

Description: The words "Court of Justice" denote a Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body.

Example Use Cases: A Magistrate's court, a Sessions Court, the High Court, and the Supreme Court are Courts of Justice.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
19.title: IPC Section 20: Court of Justice

20.text:
IPC Section 21: Public servant

Description: The words "public servant" denote a person who falls under any of the descriptions provided in the section, including government officers, judges, court officers, military personnel, jury members, arbitrators, and any person holding an office to perform a public duty.

Example Use Cases: A municipal corporator, a village sarpanch, a public university professor, and a government doctor are public servants.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
20.title: IPC Section 21: Public servant

21.text:
IPC Section 22: Movable property

Description: The words "movable property" are intended to include corporeal property of every description, except land and things attached to the earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to the earth.

Example Use Cases: Cash, jewellery, vehicles, livestock, timber once cut from a tree, and standing crops if agreed to be severed before sale are movable property.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
21.title: IPC Section 22: Movable property

22.text:
IPC Section 23: Wrongful gain

Description:  """Wrongful loss""

Example Use Cases: "Wrongful gain" is gain by unlawful means of property to which the person gaining is not legally entitled. "Wrongful loss" is the loss by unlawful means of property to which the person losing it is legally entitled.

Punishment: A thief wrongfully gains stolen property; the owner wrongfully loses it.
22.title: IPC Section 23: Wrongful gain

23.text:
IPC Section 24: Dishonestly

Description: Whoever does anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person, is said to do that thing "dishonestly".

Example Use Cases: A person intentionally submits a fake insurance claim to receive a payout (wrongful gain) and cause a loss to the insurance company.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
23.title: IPC Section 24: Dishonestly

24.text:
IPC Section 25: Fraudulently

Description: A person is said to do a thing fraudulently if he does that thing with intent to defraud but not otherwise.

Example Use Cases: Creating a fake document to deceive someone into parting with their property is acting fraudulently.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
24.title: IPC Section 25: Fraudulently

25.text:
IPC Section 26: Reason to believe

Description: A person is said to have "reason to believe" a thing if he has sufficient cause to believe that thing but not otherwise.

Example Use Cases: If a person buys a brand-new smartphone for a fraction of its price from a stranger on the street, he has reason to believe it might be stolen.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
25.title: IPC Section 26: Reason to believe

26.text:
IPC Section 27: Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant

Description: When property is in the possession of a person's wife, clerk, or servant, on account of that person, it is deemed to be in that person's possession.

Example Use Cases: Money embezzled by a company clerk is considered to be in the possession of the company owner for the purpose of establishing liability.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
26.title: IPC Section 27: Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant

27.text:
IPC Section 28: Counterfeit

Description: A person is said to "counterfeit" who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending to practice deception or knowing it to be likely that deception will be practiced.

Example Use Cases: Printing fake currency notes that resemble real notes is counterfeiting.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
27.title: IPC Section 28: Counterfeit

28.text:
IPC Section 29: Document

Description: The word "document" denotes any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures, or marks with the intention of being used as evidence.

Example Use Cases: A written contract, a printed receipt, an electronic record, a map, or even a lottery ticket are documents.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
28.title: IPC Section 29: Document

29.text:
IPC Section 29A: Electronic record

Description: "Electronic record" has the meaning assigned to it in the Information Technology Act, 2000.

Example Use Cases: An email, a digital database, a WhatsApp message, or a computer log file are electronic records.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
29.title: IPC Section 29A: Electronic record

30.text:
IPC Section 30: Valuable security

Description: A document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished, or released, is a "valuable security".

Example Use Cases: A promissory note, a share certificate, a deed of sale for a house, or a will are valuable securities.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
30.title: IPC Section 30: Valuable security

31.text:
IPC Section 31: A will

Description: The words "a will" denote any testamentary document.

Example Use Cases: A legal document that specifies how a person's property should be distributed after their death.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
31.title: IPC Section 31: A will

32.text:
IPC Section 32: Words referring to acts include illegal omissions

Description: In every part of this Code, except where a contrary intention appears from the context, words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal omissions.

Example Use Cases: The word "act" in assault includes the illegal omission of a bus driver to apply brakes, causing injury.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is an interpretative clause.
32.title: IPC Section 32: Words referring to acts include illegal omissions

33.text:
IPC Section 33: Act

Description:  """Omission""

Example Use Cases: The word "act" denotes a single act as well as a series of acts; the word "omission" denotes a single omission as well as a series of omissions.

Punishment: A person who repeatedly harasses another over several days is committing a series of acts. A guard who repeatedly fails to perform his duty is a series of omissions.
33.title: IPC Section 33: Act

34.text:
IPC Section 34: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention

Description: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

Example Use Cases: Five people plan to beat a victim. Even if only one delivers the fatal blow, all five can be charged with murder under this section read with Section 302.

Punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed, as if done individually.
34.title: IPC Section 34: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention

35.text:
IPC Section 35: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention

Description: Whenever an act, which is criminal only by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention, is done by several persons, each person who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable.

Example Use Cases: A group of people knowingly handle stolen goods; each one is liable for receiving stolen property because they all had the criminal intention.

Punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.
35.title: IPC Section 35: When such an act is criminal by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention

36.text:
IPC Section 36: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission

Description: Wherever the causing of a certain effect, or an attempt to cause that effect, by an act or by an omission, is an offence, it is to be understood that the causing of that effect partly by an act and partly by an omission is the same offence.

Example Use Cases: A nurse (act) gives a wrong medicine and then (omission) fails to monitor the patient, leading to death. She is liable for causing death.

Punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.
36.title: IPC Section 36: Effect caused partly by act and partly by omission

37.text:
IPC Section 37: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence

Description: When an offence is committed by means of several acts, whoever intentionally co-operates in the commission of that offence by doing any one of those acts is liable.

Example Use Cases: In a robbery, one person distracts the victim, another snatches the bag, and a third drives the getaway car. All co-operated and are liable for robbery.

Punishment: Liability for the specific offence committed.
37.title: IPC Section 37: Co-operation by doing one of several acts constituting an offence

38.text:
IPC Section 38: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences

Description: Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act, they may be guilty of different offences by means of that act.

Example Use Cases: A and B plan to beat C. A has a stick, B has a gun. B shoots and kills C. A may be guilty of voluntarily causing hurt, while B is guilty of murder.

Punishment: Punishment as per the different offences they are found guilty of.
38.title: IPC Section 38: Persons concerned in criminal act may be guilty of different offences

39.text:
IPC Section 39: Voluntarily

Description: A person is said to cause an effect "voluntarily" when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which he knew were likely to cause it.

Example Use Cases: A person throws a stone at a crowd, not intending to hit anyone but knowing it is likely. If someone is hit, he voluntarily caused hurt.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
39.title: IPC Section 39: Voluntarily

40.text:
IPC Section 40: Offence

Description: Except in the Chapters and sections mentioned, the word "offence" denotes a thing made punishable by this Code.

Example Use Cases: Theft, defined in Section 378 and punishable under Section 379, is an offence.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
40.title: IPC Section 40: Offence

41.text:
IPC Section 41: Special law

Description: A "special law" is a law applicable to a particular subject.

Example Use Cases: The Arms Act, the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and the Prevention of Corruption Act are special laws.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
41.title: IPC Section 41: Special law

42.text:
IPC Section 42: Local law

Description: A "local law" is a law applicable only to a particular part of India.

Example Use Cases: A state government act or a municipal bye-law is a local law.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
42.title: IPC Section 42: Local law

43.text:
IPC Section 43: Illegal

Description:  """Legally bound to do""

Example Use Cases: The word "illegal" is applicable to everything which is an offence or which is prohibited by law, or which furnishes ground for a civil action. A person is said to be "legally bound to do" anything if he is subject to a legal penalty if he fails to do it.

Punishment: Trespassing is illegal. A witness is legally bound to tell the truth in court.
43.title: IPC Section 43: Illegal

44.text:
IPC Section 44: Injury

Description: The word "injury" denotes any harm whatever illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.

Example Use Cases: Physical assault causes injury to the body; defamation causes injury to reputation.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
44.title: IPC Section 44: Injury

45.text:
IPC Section 45: Life

Description: The word "life" denotes the life of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

Example Use Cases: The offence of murder protects the "life" of a human being.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
45.title: IPC Section 45: Life

46.text:
IPC Section 46: Death

Description: The word "death" denotes the death of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

Example Use Cases: Causing the "death" of a human being is a key element in offences like culpable homicide.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
46.title: IPC Section 46: Death

47.text:
IPC Section 47: Animal

Description: The word "animal" denotes any living creature, other than a human being.

Example Use Cases: A cow, a dog, a snake, or a bird is an animal.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
47.title: IPC Section 47: Animal

48.text:
IPC Section 48: Vessel

Description: The word "vessel" denotes anything made for the conveyance by water of human beings or property.

Example Use Cases: A ship, a boat, a yacht, or a ferry is a vessel.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
48.title: IPC Section 48: Vessel

49.text:
IPC Section 49: Year

Description:  """Month""

Example Use Cases: Wherever the word "year" or "month" is used, it is to be understood that the year or month is to be reckoned according to the British calendar.

Punishment: A punishment of one year imprisonment means one year according to the Gregorian calendar.
49.title: IPC Section 49: Year

50.text:
IPC Section 50: Section

Description: The word "section" denotes one of those portions of a Chapter of this Code which are distinguished by prefixed numeral figures.

Example Use Cases: Referring to "Section 379" means the portion of the Code numbered 379.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
50.title: IPC Section 50: Section

51.text:
IPC Section 51: Oath

Description: The word "oath" includes a solemn affirmation substituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorized by law to be made before a public servant.

Example Use Cases: An atheist witness can make a solemn affirmation instead of swearing on a holy book.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
51.title: IPC Section 51: Oath

52.text:
IPC Section 52: Good faith

Description: Nothing is said to be done or believed in "good faith" which is done or believed without due care and attention.

Example Use Cases: A journalist publishing a defamatory statement without verifying the facts cannot claim it was done in good faith.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
52.title: IPC Section 52: Good faith

53.text:
IPC Section 52A: Harbour

Description: Except in Section 157, and in Section 130 in the case in which the harbour is given by the wife or husband of the person harboured, the word "harbour" includes supplying a person with shelter, food, drink, money, clothes, arms, ammunition, or means of conveyance.

Example Use Cases: Providing a hiding place, food, or money to a known fugitive from justice constitutes harbouring.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
53.title: IPC Section 52A: Harbour

54.text:
IPC Section 53: Punishments

Description: The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Code are: Death; Imprisonment for life; Imprisonment, which is of two descriptions—rigorous (with hard labour) and simple; Forfeiture of property; Fine.

Example Use Cases: A judge sentencing a convict for murder may choose between death and imprisonment for life.

Punishment: Listing of permissible punishments under the IPC.
54.title: IPC Section 53: Punishments

55.text:
IPC Section 54: Commutation of sentence of death

Description: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute a sentence of death for any other punishment provided by this Code.

Example Use Cases: The President of India commutes a death sentence to life imprisonment.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it deals with the power of commutation.
55.title: IPC Section 54: Commutation of sentence of death

56.text:
IPC Section 55: Commutation of sentence of imprisonment for life

Description: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute a sentence of imprisonment for life for imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

Example Use Cases: A state government commutes a life imprisonment term to rigorous imprisonment for ten years.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it deals with the power of commutation.
56.title: IPC Section 55: Commutation of sentence of imprisonment for life

57.text:
IPC Section 55A: Definition of “appropriate Government”

Description: In Sections 54 and 55, the expression “appropriate Government” means the Central Government where the sentence is related to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, and the State Government in other cases.

Example Use Cases: A death sentence for a crime under a central law like the NDPS Act would be commuted by the Central Government.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
57.title: IPC Section 55A: Definition of “appropriate Government”

58.text:
IPC Section 56: Sentence of Europeans and Americans to penal servitude

Description: [Repealed by the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1949]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
58.title: IPC Section 56: Sentence of Europeans and Americans to penal servitude

59.text:
IPC Section 57: Fractions of terms of punishment

Description: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years.

Example Use Cases: This is used for calculating half of a life term for an attempt under Section 511.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a calculation rule.
59.title: IPC Section 57: Fractions of terms of punishment

60.text:
IPC Section 58: Offenders sentenced to transportation how dealt with until transported

Description: [Repealed by the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1955]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
60.title: IPC Section 58: Offenders sentenced to transportation how dealt with until transported

61.text:
IPC Section 59: Transportation instead of imprisonment

Description: [Repealed by the Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1955]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
61.title: IPC Section 59: Transportation instead of imprisonment

62.text:
IPC Section 60: Sentence may be (in certain cases of imprisonment) wholly or partly rigorous or simple

Description: A court sentencing an offender to imprisonment for a term of up to one year can order that the imprisonment be wholly rigorous, wholly simple, or that part of it be rigorous and the rest simple.

Example Use Cases: A magistrate sentences a person to six months imprisonment and orders that the first three months be rigorous and the remaining three be simple.

Punishment: Specifies the court's discretion in ordering the type of imprisonment.
62.title: IPC Section 60: Sentence may be (in certain cases of imprisonment) wholly or partly rigorous or simple

63.text:
IPC Section 61: Sentence of forfeiture of property

Description: [Repealed by the Indian Penal Code (Amendment) Act, 1921]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
63.title: IPC Section 61: Sentence of forfeiture of property

64.text:
IPC Section 62: Forfeiture of property in respect of offenders punishable with death

Description: [Repealed by the Indian Penal Code (Amendment) Act, 1921]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
64.title: IPC Section 62: Forfeiture of property in respect of offenders punishable with death

65.text:
IPC Section 63: Amount of fine

Description: Where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend, the amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive.

Example Use Cases: For an offence where the punishment is stated as 'imprisonment and fine', the fine amount is at the court's discretion but must be reasonable.

Punishment: Fine to be determined by the court, must not be excessive.
65.title: IPC Section 63: Amount of fine

66.text:
IPC Section 64: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine

Description: When an offence is punishable with imprisonment and fine, the court may order that the offender shall undergo imprisonment for a certain term in default of payment of the fine. This imprisonment is in addition to the substantive imprisonment for the offence.

Example Use Cases: A person is sentenced to one year imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 5000. The court also orders that if the fine is not paid, the person will undergo an additional two months imprisonment.

Punishment: Imprisonment in default of fine payment, which is in addition to the main sentence.
66.title: IPC Section 64: Sentence of imprisonment for non-payment of fine

67.text:
IPC Section 65: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable

Description: The term of imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall not exceed one-fourth of the maximum term of imprisonment fixed for the offence.

Example Use Cases: If the maximum imprisonment for an offence is four years, the imprisonment in default of fine cannot exceed one year.

Punishment: Imprisonment in default capped at one-fourth of the maximum substantive imprisonment term.
67.title: IPC Section 65: Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable

68.text:
IPC Section 66: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine

Description: The imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall be simple.

Example Use Cases: A person unable to pay a fine will undergo simple imprisonment, not rigorous.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment.
68.title: IPC Section 66: Description of imprisonment for non-payment of fine

69.text:
IPC Section 67: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only

Description: If the offence is punishable with fine only, the imprisonment in default of payment of the fine shall be simple, and the term shall not exceed two months if the fine is not exceeding fifty rupees; four months if not exceeding one hundred rupees; and six months in any other case.

Example Use Cases: A person convicted of a minor offence with a fine of Rs. 2000 who fails to pay may be sentenced to simple imprisonment for up to six months.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment for a term based on the amount of the fine.
69.title: IPC Section 67: Imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when offence punishable with fine only

70.text:
IPC Section 68: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine

Description: The imprisonment in default of payment of a fine shall terminate whenever the fine is either paid or levied by process of law.

Example Use Cases: A person sentenced to one month in default of a fine is released immediately if the fine is paid at any time during that month.

Punishment: Termination of imprisonment upon payment or recovery of the fine.
70.title: IPC Section 68: Imprisonment to terminate on payment of fine

71.text:
IPC Section 69: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine

Description: If a part of the fine is paid, the imprisonment shall be reduced proportionally. The term shall be reduced by a fraction of the term equal to the fraction of the fine that has been paid.

Example Use Cases: A fine of Rs. 1000 carries a default sentence of one month (30 days). If Rs. 500 is paid, the default imprisonment is reduced by half, to 15 days.

Punishment: Proportional reduction of imprisonment term upon partial payment of fine.
71.title: IPC Section 69: Termination of imprisonment on payment of proportional part of fine

72.text:
IPC Section 70: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment—Death not to discharge property from liability

Description: A fine can be levied at any time within six years after the passing of the sentence. The death of the offender does not discharge their property from liability to pay the fine.

Example Use Cases: A convict avoids payment for five years; the court can still initiate recovery proceedings against their property. The fine can also be recovered from the convict's estate after their death.

Punishment: Fine can be recovered within six years and is a charge on the offender's property, even after death.
72.title: IPC Section 70: Fine leviable within six years, or during imprisonment—Death not to discharge property from liability

73.text:
IPC Section 71: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences

Description: Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such offences, unless it is so expressly provided.

Example Use Cases: A person commits theft in a building (Section 380). This offence includes the basic offence of theft (Section 379). They cannot be punished separately for both 379 and 380.

Punishment: Punishment for one offence only, usually the one with the more severe penalty.
73.title: IPC Section 71: Limit of punishment of offence made up of several offences

74.text:
IPC Section 72: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which

Description: In a case where it is doubtful which of several offences the facts proved will constitute, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided.

Example Use Cases: A person is charged with theft and receiving stolen property. The evidence is unclear. The court convicts them for receiving stolen property if it carries a lower punishment.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence with the least severe penalty.
74.title: IPC Section 72: Punishment of person guilty of one of several offences, the judgment stating that it is doubtful of which

75.text:
IPC Section 73: Solitary confinement

Description: A court can order that solitary confinement be inflicted as part of the imprisonment in certain cases. The total period of solitary confinement shall not exceed three months in any case. It must not exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals of at least fourteen days.

Example Use Cases: A convict sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for a grave crime like murder may be ordered to undergo periods of solitary confinement.

Punishment: Solitary confinement, subject to strict limits on duration and frequency.
75.title: IPC Section 73: Solitary confinement

76.text:
IPC Section 74: Limit of solitary confinement

Description: In executing a sentence of solitary confinement, such confinement shall in no case exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals of not less than fourteen days between each period of solitary confinement.

Example Use Cases: A convict cannot be kept in solitary confinement for 30 days continuously; it must be broken up into periods of no more than 14 days each.

Punishment: As per the limits described in Section 73.
76.title: IPC Section 74: Limit of solitary confinement

77.text:
IPC Section 75: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction

Description: Whoever, having been convicted of an offence under Chapter XII (Offences against property) or Chapter XVII (Offences against property), is again convicted of any offence under either of those chapters, shall be subject to enhanced punishment.

Example Use Cases: A person previously convicted of theft is convicted of theft again. The court can impose a longer term of imprisonment for the second offence.

Punishment: Imprisonment for either description for a term which may extend to double the maximum term provided for the offence.
77.title: IPC Section 75: Enhanced punishment for certain offences under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII after previous conviction

78.text:
IPC Section 76: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law believes himself to be, bound by law to do it.

Example Use Cases: A policeman, acting under a valid court warrant, arrests a person. This is not an offence of wrongful confinement.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
78.title: IPC Section 76: Act done by a person bound, or by mistake of fact believing himself bound, by law

79.text:
IPC Section 77: Act of Judge when acting judicially

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law.

Example Use Cases: A Judge orders the imprisonment of a convict. This is not an offence of wrongful confinement.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
79.title: IPC Section 77: Act of Judge when acting judicially

80.text:
IPC Section 78: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court

Description: Nothing which is done in pursuance of, or which is warranted by the judgment or order of, a Court of Justice is an offence, provided the person doing the act in good faith believes the Court had jurisdiction.

Example Use Cases: A bailiff, acting on a court order, attaches the property of a judgment debtor. This is not theft.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
80.title: IPC Section 78: Act done pursuant to the judgment or order of Court

81.text:
IPC Section 79: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by any person who is justified by law, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be justified by law, in doing it.

Example Use Cases: A person sees someone being attacked. Mistaking the attacker for the victim, he uses force against the actual victim. This is not an offence due to a mistake of fact.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
81.title: IPC Section 79: Act done by a person justified, or by mistake of fact believing himself justified, by law

82.text:
IPC Section 80: Accident in doing a lawful act

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by accident or misfortune, and without any criminal intention or knowledge, in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.

Example Use Cases: A person chopping wood lawfully and with care accidentally lets the axe slip, killing a bystander. This is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
82.title: IPC Section 80: Accident in doing a lawful act

83.text:
IPC Section 81: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm

Description: Nothing is an offence merely by reason of its being done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause harm, if it be done without any criminal intention to cause harm, and in good faith for the purpose of preventing or avoiding other harm to person or property.

Example Use Cases: To stop a fire from spreading, a person pulls down houses. This is not mischief, as it was done to prevent a greater harm.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
83.title: IPC Section 81: Act likely to cause harm, but done without criminal intent, and to prevent other harm

84.text:
IPC Section 82: Act of a child under seven years of age

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

Example Use Cases: A six-year-old child picks up and takes away a toy from a shop. This is not theft.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing absolute immunity.
84.title: IPC Section 82: Act of a child under seven years of age

85.text:
IPC Section 83: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion.

Example Use Cases: A nine-year-old child of underdeveloped intellect sets fire to a house, not understanding the consequences. This is not arson.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity if maturity is lacking.
85.title: IPC Section 83: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding

86.text:
IPC Section 84: Act of a person of unsound mind

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

Example Use Cases: A person in a manic episode, believing they are destroying evil spirits, breaks valuable items. This may not be mischief.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
86.title: IPC Section 84: Act of a person of unsound mind

87.text:
IPC Section 85: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.

Example Use Cases: A person is forcibly administered an intoxicating drug and, while in that state, commits assault. This is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
87.title: IPC Section 85: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will

88.text:
IPC Section 86: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated

Description: In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the intoxication was caused without his knowledge or against his will.

Example Use Cases: A person voluntarily gets drunk and, while intoxicated, commits an assault. His voluntary intoxication is not a defence, and he can be held liable as if he were sober.

Punishment: Liable for the offence, as voluntary intoxication is not a defence for forming intent.
88.title: IPC Section 86: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated

89.text:
IPC Section 87: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent

Description: Nothing is an offence which is not intended to cause death or grievous hurt, and which is done by the consent of the person above eighteen years of age who understands the risk involved.

Example Use Cases: A person consents to a surgical operation by a doctor. The operation is not an assault. Participating in a rough game like rugby where hurt is likely is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
89.title: IPC Section 87: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent

90.text:
IPC Section 88: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit

Description: Nothing which is not intended to cause death is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to the person consenting, if it is done in good faith for that person's benefit.

Example Use Cases: A surgeon, with consent, performs a risky but necessary operation that results in harm. This is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
90.title: IPC Section 88: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person's benefit

91.text:
IPC Section 89: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian

Description: Nothing which is done in good faith for the benefit of a person under twelve years of age or of unsound mind, by or by consent of the guardian, is an offence by reason of any harm it may cause.

Example Use Cases: A guardian of a minor consents to a necessary medical procedure for the child. A parent physically chastising a child for correction is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
91.title: IPC Section 89: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or insane person, by or by consent of guardian

92.text:
IPC Section 90: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception

Description: A consent is not a valid consent within the meaning of Sections 87, 88 and 89 if it is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact, or by an insane or intoxicated person, or by a child unless the contrary appears from the context.

Example Use Cases: A person consents to sexual intercourse under a threat of violence. This consent is invalid, making it rape. A patient consents to an operation believing it is for a different purpose.

Punishment: Consent is vitiated and cannot be used as a defence.
92.title: IPC Section 90: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception

93.text:
IPC Section 91: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused

Description: The exceptions in Sections 87, 88 and 89 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause.

Example Use Cases: Causing a miscarriage is an offence under Section 312, even if the woman consents. Consent is no defence.

Punishment: The act remains an offence despite consent.
93.title: IPC Section 91: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused

94.text:
IPC Section 92: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent

Description: Nothing is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to a person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, even without that person's consent, if circumstances exist that make it impossible to obtain consent and the doer believes the consent would have been given.

Example Use Cases: A doctor performs an emergency life-saving operation on an unconscious patient after an accident. This is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
94.title: IPC Section 92: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent

95.text:
IPC Section 93: Communication made in good faith

Description: No communication made in good faith is an offence by reason of any harm to the person to whom it is made, if it is made for the benefit of that person.

Example Use Cases: A doctor truthfully tells a patient they have a serious illness. This is not defamation or causing emotional distress.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
95.title: IPC Section 93: Communication made in good faith

96.text:
IPC Section 94: Act to which a person is compelled by threats

Description: Except for murder and offences against the state punishable with death, nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is compelled to do it by threats, which, at the time of doing it, reasonably cause the apprehension that instant death to that person will otherwise be the consequence.

Example Use Cases: A person is threatened with instant death unless they assist in a robbery. Their participation in the robbery is not an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
96.title: IPC Section 94: Act to which a person is compelled by threats

97.text:
IPC Section 95: Act causing slight harm

Description: Nothing is an offence which causes, or intends to cause, harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of it.

Example Use Cases: A person pushes another slightly in a crowded bus. This is not assault.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
97.title: IPC Section 95: Act causing slight harm

98.text:
IPC Section 96: Things done in private defence

Description: Nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence.

Example Use Cases: A person has the right to defend their own body and property against an offence.

Punishment: Not an offence; this is a general exception providing immunity.
98.title: IPC Section 96: Things done in private defence

99.text:
IPC Section 97: Right of private defence of the body and of property

Description: Every person has a right, subject to the restrictions in Section 99, to defend their own body and the body of any other person against any offence affecting the human body. They also have the same right to defend their own property or the property of any other person against certain offences like theft, robbery, mischief, or criminal trespass.

Example Use Cases: A person can use force to prevent a thief from stealing their car. A person can defend a friend who is being attacked.

Punishment: The right to use necessary force, extending even to causing death in certain grave situations.
99.title: IPC Section 97: Right of private defence of the body and of property

100.text:
IPC Section 98: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.

Description: When an act which would otherwise be a certain offence is not that offence due to youth, want of maturity of understanding, unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or misconception, the right of private defence against that act is the same as it would be if the act were that offence.

Example Use Cases: A person attacked by a child or a lunatic can still exercise the right of private defence to the same extent as if the attacker were a sane adult.

Punishment: The right to private defence exists even against acts of exempted persons.
100.title: IPC Section 98: Right of private defence against the act of a person of unsound mind, etc.

101.text:
IPC Section 99: Acts against which there is no right of private defence

Description: The right of private defence does not extend to causing more harm than is necessary for defence. There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or grievous hurt, if done by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of their office. There is no right against an act done under the direction of a public servant.

Example Use Cases: A person cannot shoot a pickpocket. A person cannot resist a lawful arrest by a police officer.

Punishment: No right to defend exists in these scenarios.
101.title: IPC Section 99: Acts against which there is no right of private defence

102.text:
IPC Section 100: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death

Description: The right of private defence of the body extends to voluntarily causing death if the offence which occasions the exercise of the right is of any of the following types: assault reasonably causing apprehension of death; assault reasonably causing apprehension of grievous hurt; assault with intention of committing rape; assault with intention of gratifying unnatural lust; assault with intention of kidnapping or abducting; assault with intention of wrongfully confining a person.

Example Use Cases: A woman can kill a man attempting to rape her. A person can kill an attacker who is trying to kidnap their child.

Punishment: The right extends to causing the death of the assailant.
102.title: IPC Section 100: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death

103.text:
IPC Section 101: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death

Description: If the offence is not of any of the types enumerated in Section 100, the right of private defence of the body extends to causing any harm other than death.

Example Use Cases: Defending against an assault that only causes or threatens to cause simple hurt.

Punishment: The right extends to causing any harm short of death.
103.title: IPC Section 101: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death

104.text:
IPC Section 102: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of the body

Description: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence, and it continues as long as such apprehension of danger to the body continues.

Example Use Cases: The right starts not when the blow is struck, but when the threat is perceived. It ends when the attacker retreats or is disabled.

Punishment: The right is available for the duration of the threat.
104.title: IPC Section 102: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of the body

105.text:
IPC Section 103: When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death

Description: The right of private defence of property extends to voluntarily causing death when the offence which occasions the exercise of the right is of any of the following descriptions: robbery; house-breaking by night; mischief by fire on any building, tent, or vessel used as a human dwelling; theft, mischief, or house-trespass which reasonably causes apprehension of death or grievous hurt.

Example Use Cases: A homeowner can kill a robber breaking into their house at night. A person can kill someone setting fire to their house.

Punishment: The right extends to causing the death of the wrongdoer.
105.title: IPC Section 103: When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death

106.text:
IPC Section 104: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death

Description: If the offence is not of any of the types enumerated in Section 103, the right of private defence of property extends to causing any harm other than death.

Example Use Cases: Defending property against simple theft or mischief during the day.

Punishment: The right extends to causing any harm short of death.
106.title: IPC Section 104: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death

107.text:
IPC Section 105: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of property

Description: The right of private defence of property commences when a reasonable apprehension of danger to the property begins. It continues against theft as long as the offender continues in the commission of theft or until the property is recovered. It continues against robbery during the continuance of the robbery. It continues against criminal trespass or mischief as long as the offender continues in the commission of such trespass or mischief.

Example Use Cases: The right to defend property against a thief continues until the stolen property is recovered or the thief escapes.

Punishment: The right is available for the duration of the criminal act against property.
107.title: IPC Section 105: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of property

108.text:
IPC Section 106: Right of private defence against deadly assault when there is risk of harm to innocent person

Description: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes apprehension of death, the defender is so situated that they cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, their right extends to the running of that risk.

Example Use Cases: A person attacked in a crowded market can return fire even if there is a risk of hitting a bystander, provided the private defence right exists.

Punishment: The right extends to taking the risk of harming an innocent person.
108.title: IPC Section 106: Right of private defence against deadly assault when there is risk of harm to innocent person

109.text:
IPC Section 107: Abetment of a thing

Description: A person abets the doing of a thing if they instigate any person to do that thing, engage with one or more other persons in a conspiracy for the doing of that thing, or intentionally aid the doing of that thing.

Example Use Cases: Persuading someone to commit a crime, conspiring to commit a crime, or providing tools to commit a crime.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted, as per Section 109 onwards.
109.title: IPC Section 107: Abetment of a thing

110.text:
IPC Section 108: Abettor

Description: An abettor is a person who abets an offence or who abets either the commission of an offence or the commission of an act which would be an offence if committed by a person capable of committing an offence.

Example Use Cases: A person who aids a minor in committing theft is an abettor, even though the minor may not be punishable.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted.
110.title: IPC Section 108: Abettor

111.text:
IPC Section 108A: Abetment in India of offences outside India

Description: A person abets an offence outside India which would be punishable in India if committed in India. They can be tried in India for abetment.

Example Use Cases: A person in Mumbai instigates someone in Nepal to commit murder in Nepal. They can be tried in India for abetting murder.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence abetted.
111.title: IPC Section 108A: Abetment in India of offences outside India

112.text:
IPC Section 109: Punishment of abetment if the act abetted is committed in consequence and where no express provision is made for its punishment

Description: Whoever abets any offence shall, if the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence.

Example Use Cases: A person instigates another to commit murder, and the murder is committed. The instigator is punished as a murderer.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence committed.
112.title: IPC Section 109: Punishment of abetment if the act abetted is committed in consequence and where no express provision is made for its punishment

113.text:
IPC Section 110: Punishment of abetment if person abetted does act with different intention from that of abettor

Description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence shall be punished with the punishment provided for the offence, even if the person abetted acts with a different intention or knowledge from that of the abettor.

Example Use Cases: A abets B to burn Z's house. B, while doing so, also commits theft. A is guilty of abetting burning (mischief by fire), not theft.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence which was abetted.
113.title: IPC Section 110: Punishment of abetment if person abetted does act with different intention from that of abettor

114.text:
IPC Section 111: Liability of abettor when one act abetted and different act done

Description: When an act is abetted and a different act is done, the abettor is liable for the act done in the same manner as if they had abetted that act, provided the act done was a probable consequence of the abetment and was committed under the influence of the instigation.

Example Use Cases: A instigates a child to put poison in B's food. The child, by mistake, puts the poison in C's food. A is liable for the murder of C.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence actually committed, if it was a probable consequence of the abetment.
114.title: IPC Section 111: Liability of abettor when one act abetted and different act done

115.text:
IPC Section 112: Abettor when liable to cumulative punishment for act abetted and for act done

Description: If the act for which the abettor is liable under Section 111 is committed in addition to the act abetted, and constitutes a distinct offence, the abettor is liable for punishment for each of the offences.

Example Use Cases: A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. B does so, and also wrongfully confines Z. A is liable for abetting grievous hurt and also for the wrongful confinement if it was a probable consequence.

Punishment: Cumulative punishment for both the abetted offence and the offence committed as a consequence.
115.title: IPC Section 112: Abettor when liable to cumulative punishment for act abetted and for act done

116.text:
IPC Section 113: Liability of abettor for an effect caused by the act abetted different from that intended by the abettor

Description: When an act is abetted with the intention of causing a particular effect, and an act for which the abettor is liable results in a different effect, the abettor is liable for the effect caused in the same manner as if they had abetted the act with the intention of causing that effect.

Example Use Cases: A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. B causes such hurt, and Z dies. A is liable for abetting culpable homicide.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence which was the actual result of the abetted act.
116.title: IPC Section 113: Liability of abettor for an effect caused by the act abetted different from that intended by the abettor

117.text:
IPC Section 114: Abettor present when offence is committed

Description: Whenever any person who is an abettor in the commission of an offence is present when the offence is committed, they shall be deemed to have committed the offence itself.

Example Use Cases: A instigates B to murder Z. A is present and assists when B murders Z. A is not just an abettor but is treated as having committed the murder himself.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence committed, not just for abetment.
117.title: IPC Section 114: Abettor present when offence is committed

118.text:
IPC Section 115: Abetment of offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life—if offence not committed

Description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life shall, if that offence is not committed, be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, the abettor is punished as per Section 109.

Example Use Cases: A instigates B to murder Z. The murder is not committed. A can be imprisoned for up to seven years.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
118.title: IPC Section 115: Abetment of offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life—if offence not committed

119.text:
IPC Section 116: Abetment of offence punishable with imprisonment—if offence not committed

Description: Whoever abets an offence punishable with imprisonment shall, if that offence is not committed, be punished with imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence, or with fine, or both. If the abettor is a public servant and the offence is related to their duty, the imprisonment can extend to one-half of the maximum term.

Example Use Cases: A, a public servant, abets B to commit theft. The theft does not occur. A can be punished with imprisonment up to half of the maximum term for theft (which is 3 years, so up to 1.5 years).

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one-fourth (or one-half for public servants) of the maximum term for the offence, or fine, or both.
119.title: IPC Section 116: Abetment of offence punishable with imprisonment—if offence not committed

120.text:
IPC Section 117: Abetting commission of offence by the public or by more than ten persons

Description: Whoever abets the commission of an offence by the public generally or by any number or class of persons exceeding ten, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or both.

Example Use Cases: Making a public speech instigating a large mob to burn down a particular community's houses.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
120.title: IPC Section 117: Abetting commission of offence by the public or by more than ten persons

121.text:
IPC Section 118: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life

Description: Whoever intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that they will facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, voluntarily conceals the existence of a design to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If the offence is committed, the punishment is up to seven years.

Example Use Cases: A knows that B is planning to murder Z and hides this information from the authorities to help B.

Punishment: If offence not committed: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If offence committed: Imprisonment up to seven years.
121.title: IPC Section 118: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life

122.text:
IPC Section 119: Public servant concealing design to commit offence which it is their duty to prevent

Description: A public servant who intends to facilitate or knows it will facilitate the commission of an offence which they are duty-bound to prevent, and conceals the design of that offence, shall be punished. If the offence is punishable with death/imprisonment for life, imprisonment up to ten years. For any other offence, imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.

Example Use Cases: A police officer knows a robbery is being planned but does nothing to prevent it and conceals the information.

Punishment: If offence is serious: Imprisonment up to ten years. For other offences: Imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
122.title: IPC Section 119: Public servant concealing design to commit offence which it is their duty to prevent

123.text:
IPC Section 120: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

Description: Whoever, intending to facilitate or knowing it will facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment, voluntarily conceals the existence of a design to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence, or with fine, or both. If the offence is committed, imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term.

Example Use Cases: A knows B plans to commit simple hurt and conceals it. The maximum for simple hurt is one year, so A can be imprisoned for up to three months.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for the offence, or fine, or both.
123.title: IPC Section 120: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

124.text:
IPC Section 120A: Definition of criminal conspiracy

Description: When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done, an illegal act, or an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy.

Example Use Cases: A and B agree to poison Z. This is a criminal conspiracy to commit murder.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 120B.
124.title: IPC Section 120A: Definition of criminal conspiracy

125.text:
IPC Section 120B: Punishment of criminal conspiracy

Description: Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for two years or more shall be punished in the same manner as if they had abetted such offence. A party to a criminal conspiracy to commit any other offence shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

Example Use Cases: Conspiring to commit murder is punishable as abetment of murder. Conspiring to commit a minor theft is punishable with up to six months imprisonment.

Punishment: For serious offences: Punishment for abetment of that offence. For other offences: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
125.title: IPC Section 120B: Punishment of criminal conspiracy

126.text:
IPC Section 121: Waging, or attempting to wage war, or abetting waging of war, against the Government of India

Description: Whoever wages war against the Government of India, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Leading an armed insurrection against the Indian state.

Punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine.
126.title: IPC Section 121: Waging, or attempting to wage war, or abetting waging of war, against the Government of India

127.text:
IPC Section 121A: Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by Section 121

Description: Whoever within or without India conspires to commit any of the offences punishable by Section 121, or to deprive the Government of India of its sovereignty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

Example Use Cases: A group of people in a foreign country plan an armed attack on Indian soil to overthrow the government.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
127.title: IPC Section 121A: Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by Section 121

128.text:
IPC Section 122: Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war against the Government of India

Description: Whoever collects men, arms, or ammunition or otherwise prepares to wage war with the intention of waging war against the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

Example Use Cases: Stockpiling weapons and recruiting people for an armed rebellion.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
128.title: IPC Section 122: Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war against the Government of India

129.text:
IPC Section 123: Concealing with intent to facilitate design to wage war

Description: Whoever by any act, or by any illegal omission, conceals the existence of a design to wage war, intending to facilitate the waging of war, shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Knowing about a plot to wage war and hiding it from the authorities to help the plotters.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
129.title: IPC Section 123: Concealing with intent to facilitate design to wage war

130.text:
IPC Section 124: Assaulting President, Governor, etc., with intent to compel or restrain the exercise of any lawful power

Description: Whoever assaults the President of India, or the Governor of any State, with the intent to compel or restrain them from exercising any lawful power, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Assaulting the President to force them to resign.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
130.title: IPC Section 124: Assaulting President, Governor, etc., with intent to compel or restrain the exercise of any lawful power

131.text:
IPC Section 124A: Sedition

Description: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representation, or otherwise, brings or attempts to bring into hatred or contempt, or excites or attempts to excite disaffection towards the Government established by law in India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life (to which fine may be added), or imprisonment up to three years (to which fine may be added), or fine.

Example Use Cases: Making speeches or publishing articles that incite violence or public disorder against the government.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life (with possible fine), or imprisonment up to three years (with possible fine), or fine.
131.title: IPC Section 124A: Sedition

132.text:
IPC Section 125: Waging war against any Asiatic power in alliance with the Government of India

Description: Whoever wages war against the Government of any Asiatic power in alliance or at peace with the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, to which fine may be added, or imprisonment up to seven years, to which fine may be added, or fine.

Example Use Cases: An Indian citizen joining a rebel army to fight against a friendly neighbouring country's government.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life (with possible fine), or imprisonment up to seven years (with possible fine), or fine.
132.title: IPC Section 125: Waging war against any Asiatic power in alliance with the Government of India

133.text:
IPC Section 126: Committing depredation on territories of power at peace with the Government of India

Description: Whoever commits depredation, or prepares to commit depredation, on the territories of any power in alliance or at peace with the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of property used in the depredation.

Example Use Cases: A private militia from India raids a village across the border in a friendly country.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of property.
133.title: IPC Section 126: Committing depredation on territories of power at peace with the Government of India

134.text:
IPC Section 127: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 and 126

Description: Whoever receives any property knowing it to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126, shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of the property.

Example Use Cases: Buying looted goods that were taken during a raid on a friendly country.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine, and forfeiture of the property.
134.title: IPC Section 127: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 and 126

135.text:
IPC Section 128: Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of state or war to escape

Description: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any state prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

Example Use Cases: A jailor deliberately lets a captured enemy combatant escape.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
135.title: IPC Section 128: Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of state or war to escape

136.text:
IPC Section 129: Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of state or war to escape

Description: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any state prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape, shall be punished with simple imprisonment up to three years and fine.

Example Use Cases: A guard falls asleep on duty, allowing a high-security prisoner to escape.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to three years and fine.
136.title: IPC Section 129: Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of state or war to escape

137.text:
IPC Section 130: Aiding escape of, rescuing, or harbouring such prisoner

Description: Whoever knowingly aids or assists any state prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue such prisoner, or harbours or conceals such prisoner who has escaped, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Providing a getaway car to a prisoner of war who has broken out of jail.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
137.title: IPC Section 130: Aiding escape of, rescuing, or harbouring such prisoner

138.text:
IPC Section 130A: [Repealed]

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
138.title: IPC Section 130A: [Repealed]

139.text:
IPC Section 130B: [Repealed]

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
139.title: IPC Section 130B: [Repealed]

140.text:
IPC Section 131: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce a soldier, sailor or airman from his duty

Description: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, or attempts to seduce any such person from his allegiance or duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Trying to persuade an army jawan to desert his post during a conflict.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
140.title: IPC Section 131: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce a soldier, sailor or airman from his duty

141.text:
IPC Section 132: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny is committed in consequence thereof

Description: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny shall, if mutiny is committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Instigating a group of soldiers to mutiny, which they then do.

Punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
141.title: IPC Section 132: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny is committed in consequence thereof

142.text:
IPC Section 133: Abetment of assault by soldier, sailor or airman on his superior officer, when in execution of his office

Description: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman on his superior officer in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years and fine.

Example Use Cases: Encouraging a soldier to hit his commanding officer who is giving a lawful order.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
142.title: IPC Section 133: Abetment of assault by soldier, sailor or airman on his superior officer, when in execution of his office

143.text:
IPC Section 134: Abetment of such assault, if the assault is committed

Description: Whoever abets an assault described in Section 133 shall, if the assault is committed, be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

Example Use Cases: The abetment described in Section 133 actually results in the assault taking place.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
143.title: IPC Section 134: Abetment of such assault, if the assault is committed

144.text:
IPC Section 135: Abetment of desertion of soldier, sailor or airman

Description: Whoever abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

Example Use Cases: Helping a soldier plan his unauthorized departure from the army.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
144.title: IPC Section 135: Abetment of desertion of soldier, sailor or airman

145.text:
IPC Section 136: Harbouring deserter

Description: Whoever, knowing that an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman has deserted, harbours him, shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.

Example Use Cases: Giving shelter and hiding a deserter from the army.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
145.title: IPC Section 136: Harbouring deserter

146.text:
IPC Section 137: Deserter concealed on board merchant vessel through negligence of master

Description: The master or person in charge of a merchant vessel negligently suffers a deserter from the Army, Navy, or Air Force to be concealed on board, shall be punished with fine up to five hundred rupees.

Example Use Cases: A ship captain fails to check his crew properly and unknowingly hires a deserter.

Punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.
146.title: IPC Section 137: Deserter concealed on board merchant vessel through negligence of master

147.text:
IPC Section 138: Abetment of act of insubordination by soldier, sailor or airman
