Description: Whoever abets an act of insubordination by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Army, Navy, or Air Force of India, shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.

Example Use Cases: Encouraging a soldier to willfully disobey a lawful command from a superior.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
147.title: IPC Section 138: Abetment of act of insubordination by soldier, sailor or airman

148.text:
IPC Section 139: Persons subject to certain Acts

Description: No person subject to the Army Act, the Navy Act, or the Air Force Act is subject to punishment under this Code for any offence defined in this Chapter (Chapter VII).

Example Use Cases: A soldier committing mutiny is tried under the Army Act, not under the IPC sections for mutiny.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it specifies the jurisdiction of military law.
148.title: IPC Section 139: Persons subject to certain Acts

149.text:
IPC Section 140: Wearing garb or carrying token used by soldier, sailor or airman

Description: Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor, or airman in the Military, Naval, or Air Forces, wears any garb or carries any token resembling one used by such forces with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor, or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

Example Use Cases: A civilian wears an army uniform to impersonate a soldier and gain respect or privileges.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
149.title: IPC Section 140: Wearing garb or carrying token used by soldier, sailor or airman

150.text:
IPC Section 141: Unlawful assembly

Description: An assembly of five or more persons is designated an "unlawful assembly" if the common object of the persons composing that assembly is to overawe the government by criminal force; to resist the execution of any law or legal process; to commit mischief, criminal trespass or other offence; to use criminal force to obtain possession of property or to deprive any person of any incorporeal right; or to use criminal force to compel any person to do what he is not legally bound to do.

Example Use Cases: A mob of people gathering to forcefully prevent a lawful eviction.

Punishment: Not a penal section by itself; defines the term for subsequent sections.
150.title: IPC Section 141: Unlawful assembly

151.text:
IPC Section 142: Being member of unlawful assembly

Description: Whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly.

Example Use Cases: A person joins a protest that has turned violent, knowing that the crowd is now intent on damaging public property.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 143.
151.title: IPC Section 142: Being member of unlawful assembly

152.text:
IPC Section 143: Punishment for unlawful assembly

Description: Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Simply being part of a riotous mob of five or more people with a common illegal object.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
152.title: IPC Section 143: Punishment for unlawful assembly

153.text:
IPC Section 144: Joining unlawful assembly armed with deadly weapon

Description: Whoever, being armed with any deadly weapon, or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person is part of an unlawful mob while carrying a sword, knife, or iron rod.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
153.title: IPC Section 144: Joining unlawful assembly armed with deadly weapon

154.text:
IPC Section 145: Joining or continuing in unlawful assembly, knowing it has been commanded to disperse

Description: Whoever joins or continues in an unlawful assembly, knowing that such unlawful assembly has been commanded in the manner prescribed by law to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person remains part of a riotous mob even after a police officer has read out a legal order for the crowd to disperse.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
154.title: IPC Section 145: Joining or continuing in unlawful assembly, knowing it has been commanded to disperse

155.text:
IPC Section 146: Rioting

Description: Whenever force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly, or by any member thereof, in prosecution of the common object of such assembly, every member of such assembly is guilty of the offence of rioting.

Example Use Cases: A mob with the common object of damaging a shop proceeds to break its windows and loot its goods. Every member is guilty of rioting.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 147.
155.title: IPC Section 146: Rioting

156.text:
IPC Section 147: Punishment for rioting

Description: Whoever is guilty of rioting, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Participating in a violent mob action.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
156.title: IPC Section 147: Punishment for rioting

157.text:
IPC Section 148: Rioting, armed with deadly weapon

Description: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with a deadly weapon or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person participates in a riot while carrying a firearm, axe, or sharp weapon.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
157.title: IPC Section 148: Rioting, armed with deadly weapon

158.text:
IPC Section 149: Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object

Description: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed in prosecution of that object, every person who, at the time of the committing of that offence, is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.

Example Use Cases: A mob's common object is to beat a person. One member kills that person. Every member of the mob can be charged with murder, as it was a likely consequence of their common object.

Punishment: Liable for the same punishment as for the offence committed.
158.title: IPC Section 149: Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object

159.text:
IPC Section 150: Hiring, or conniving at hiring, of persons to join unlawful assembly

Description: Whoever hires or engages, or employs, or promotes, or connives at the hiring, engagement or employment of any person to join or become a member of any unlawful assembly, shall be punishable as a member of such unlawful assembly, and for any offence which may be committed by any such person.

Example Use Cases: A community leader pays people to form a mob to attack a rival community's property. The leader is liable for the rioting and any damage caused.

Punishment: Punishment as if they were a member of the unlawful assembly for any offence committed.
159.title: IPC Section 150: Hiring, or conniving at hiring, of persons to join unlawful assembly

160.text:
IPC Section 151: Knowingly joining or continuing in assembly of five or more persons after it has been commanded to disperse

Description: Whoever knowingly joins or continues in any assembly of five or more persons likely to cause a disturbance of the public peace, after such assembly has been lawfully commanded to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person continues to be part of an unarmed but disruptive protest after a valid police order to disperse.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
160.title: IPC Section 151: Knowingly joining or continuing in assembly of five or more persons after it has been commanded to disperse

161.text:
IPC Section 152: Assaulting or obstructing public servant when suppressing riot, etc.

Description: Whoever assaults or threatens to assault, or obstructs or attempts to obstruct, any public servant in the discharge of his duty as a public servant, in endeavouring to disperse an unlawful assembly, or to suppress a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Throwing stones at police officers who are trying to control a riot.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
161.title: IPC Section 152: Assaulting or obstructing public servant when suppressing riot, etc.

162.text:
IPC Section 153: Wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot

Description: Whoever malignantly, or wantonly, by doing anything which is illegal, gives provocation to any person intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause the offence of rioting to be committed, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Making a highly inflammatory speech in a volatile area with the intention of sparking a communal riot.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
162.title: IPC Section 153: Wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot

163.text:
IPC Section 153A: Promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony

Description: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representations, or otherwise, promotes or attempts to promote, on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, caste or community or any other ground, disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred or ill-will between different groups, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Publishing content online that vilifies a particular religious community and incites hatred against them.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If committed in a place of worship, etc., imprisonment up to five years and fine.
163.title: IPC Section 153A: Promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony

164.text:
IPC Section 153B: Imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration

Description: Whoever makes or publishes any imputation that any class of persons cannot, by reason of their being members of any religious, racial, language or regional group or caste or community, bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution or uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Claiming that a particular linguistic group is inherently disloyal to the nation.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
164.title: IPC Section 153B: Imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration

165.text:
IPC Section 154: Owner or occupier of land on which an unlawful assembly is held

Description: Whenever any unlawful assembly or riot takes place, the owner or occupier of the land upon which such unlawful assembly is held, or such riot is committed, who does not use all lawful means to prevent it and to disperse the assembly, shall be punished with fine up to one thousand rupees.

Example Use Cases: The owner of a field sees a large armed mob gathering on his property and does nothing to stop them or inform the police.

Punishment: Fine up to one thousand rupees.
165.title: IPC Section 154: Owner or occupier of land on which an unlawful assembly is held

166.text:
IPC Section 155: Liability of person for whose benefit riot is committed

Description: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit or on behalf of any person who is the owner or occupier of any land, such person shall be punishable with fine if he does not use all lawful means to prevent such riot.

Example Use Cases: A factory owner benefits when a mob attacks a workers' union office. He can be fined if he knew about it and did nothing to prevent it.

Punishment: Fine.
166.title: IPC Section 155: Liability of person for whose benefit riot is committed

167.text:
IPC Section 156: Liability of agent of owner or occupier for whose benefit riot is committed

Description: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit of any person who is the owner or occupier of any land, the agent of such person shall be punishable with fine if he did not use all lawful means to prevent such riot.

Example Use Cases: The manager of an estate who fails to prevent a riot that benefits the estate owner.

Punishment: Fine.
167.title: IPC Section 156: Liability of agent of owner or occupier for whose benefit riot is committed

168.text:
IPC Section 157: Harbouring persons hired for an unlawful assembly

Description: Whoever harbours, receives or assembles any persons, knowing that such persons have been hired, engaged or employed to join an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Providing food and shelter to people who have been paid to be part of a violent protest.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
168.title: IPC Section 157: Harbouring persons hired for an unlawful assembly

169.text:
IPC Section 158: Being hired to take part in an unlawful assembly or riot

Description: Whoever is engaged or hired to offer himself to be a member of an unlawful assembly or to join in a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person accepts money to participate in a mob that will block a highway and cause violence.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
169.title: IPC Section 158: Being hired to take part in an unlawful assembly or riot

170.text:
IPC Section 159: Affray

Description: When two or more persons, by fighting in a public place, disturb the public peace, they are said to "commit an affray".

Example Use Cases: Two people get into a fistfight on a busy street, causing a scene and disturbing the peace.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 160.
170.title: IPC Section 159: Affray

171.text:
IPC Section 160: Punishment for committing affray

Description: Whoever commits an affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine up to one hundred rupees, or with both.

Example Use Cases: The punishment for the two people fighting in the public street.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to one hundred rupees, or both.
171.title: IPC Section 160: Punishment for committing affray

178.text:
IPC Section 166: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law as to the way in which he is to conduct himself as such public servant, intending to cause injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer knowingly violates arrest procedures to harass or frame an innocent person.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
178.title: IPC Section 166: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person

179.text:
IPC Section 167: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being charged with the preparation or translation of any document, frames that document in a manner he knows to be incorrect, with intent to cause injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A revenue officer intentionally prepares a faulty land record to deprive the true owner of their property.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
179.title: IPC Section 167: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury

180.text:
IPC Section 168: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to engage in trade, engages in trade, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A government officer, prohibited from running a business, secretly owns a private company.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
180.title: IPC Section 168: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade

181.text:
IPC Section 169: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to purchase or bid for certain property, purchases or bids for that property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A court officer involved in an auction purchases property that is being auctioned by his own court.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both; the property may also be confiscated.
181.title: IPC Section 169: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property

182.text:
IPC Section 170: Personating a public servant

Description: Whoever pretends to hold any particular office as a public servant, knowing that he does not hold such office, and does any act under colour of such office, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person dresses as a police officer and conducts a fake raid to extort money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
182.title: IPC Section 170: Personating a public servant

183.text:
IPC Section 171: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent

Description: Whoever, not belonging to a certain class of public servants, wears any garb or carries any token resembling one used by that class of public servants, with the intention that it may be believed that he belongs to that class, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person wears a fake government ID card to gain unauthorized entry into a secure building.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.
183.title: IPC Section 171: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent

184.text:
IPC Section 171A: Definition of “candidate” and “electoral right”

Description: For the purposes of this Chapter (Chapter IXA), "candidate" means a person who has been nominated as a candidate at an election. "Electoral right" means the right of a person to stand as a candidate, or to vote.

Example Use Cases: Defines terms used in the following sections related to elections.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
184.title: IPC Section 171A: Definition of “candidate” and “electoral right”

185.text:
IPC Section 171B: Bribery

Description: Whoever gives a gratification to any person with the object of inducing him to exercise his electoral right in a particular way, or to reward him for having done so, commits bribery. Similarly, whoever accepts such gratification also commits bribery.

Example Use Cases: Giving money to voters to vote for a specific candidate.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. If committed by a person who was a candidate, imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
185.title: IPC Section 171B: Bribery

186.text:
IPC Section 171C: Undue influence at elections

Description: Whoever voluntarily interferes or attempts to interfere with the free exercise of any electoral right, by threatening injury, or by inducing a belief that divine displeasure will follow, commits the offence of undue influence.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to evict a tenant if they do not vote for a particular candidate.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
186.title: IPC Section 171C: Undue influence at elections

187.text:
IPC Section 171D: Personation at elections

Description: Whoever at an election applies for a voting paper or votes in the name of another person, whether living or dead, or in a fictitious name, or who votes more than once, commits personation.

Example Use Cases: A person votes using a dead relative's name.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
187.title: IPC Section 171D: Personation at elections

188.text:
IPC Section 171E: Punishment for bribery

Description: Whoever commits the offence of bribery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Punishment for the act of bribery defined in Section 171B.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
188.title: IPC Section 171E: Punishment for bribery

189.text:
IPC Section 171F: Punishment for undue influence or personation at an election

Description: Whoever commits the offence of undue influence or personation at an election shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Punishment for the acts defined in Sections 171C and 171D.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
189.title: IPC Section 171F: Punishment for undue influence or personation at an election

190.text:
IPC Section 171G: False statement in connection with an election

Description: Whoever with intent to affect the result of an election makes or publishes any statement purporting to be a statement of fact which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, in relation to the personal character or conduct of any candidate, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Spreading a false rumor that a candidate has a criminal record.

Punishment: Fine.
190.title: IPC Section 171G: False statement in connection with an election

191.text:
IPC Section 171H: Illegal payments in connection with elections

Description: Whoever without the general or special authority in writing of a candidate incurs or authorizes expenses on account of the holding of any public meeting, or upon any advertisement, circular or publication, for the purpose of promoting the election of such candidate, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A supporter prints and distributes campaign posters for a candidate without the candidate's authorization.

Punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.
191.title: IPC Section 171H: Illegal payments in connection with elections

192.text:
IPC Section 171I: Failure to keep election accounts

Description: Whoever, being required by any law to keep accounts of expenses incurred in connection with an election, fails to keep such accounts, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A candidate does not maintain a record of their election campaign spending as required by law.

Punishment: Fine up to five hundred rupees.
192.title: IPC Section 171I: Failure to keep election accounts

193.text:
IPC Section 172: Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceeding

Description: Whoever absconds in order to avoid being served with a summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A witness in a case deliberately hides to avoid receiving a summons to appear in court.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
193.title: IPC Section 172: Absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceeding

194.text:
IPC Section 173: Preventing service of summons or other proceeding, or preventing publication thereof

Description: Whoever in any manner prevents the serving on himself or on any other person of any summons, notice or order, or prevents the lawful affixing of any such document, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person refuses to open the door to a process server who is trying to serve a court notice.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
194.title: IPC Section 173: Preventing service of summons or other proceeding, or preventing publication thereof

195.text:
IPC Section 174: Not obeying a legal order to attend at a certain place in person or by agent

Description: Whoever, being legally bound to appear in person at a certain place, intentionally omits to appear, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person who is summoned to court as a witness deliberately does not show up.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
195.title: IPC Section 174: Not obeying a legal order to attend at a certain place in person or by agent

196.text:
IPC Section 174A: Non-appearance in response to a proclamation under section 82 of CrPC

Description: Whoever fails to appear at the specified place and time as required by a proclamation published under subsection (1) of section 82 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A declared absconder continues to evade arrest after a court has issued a proclamation.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If the proclamation was for a bailable offence, imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees.
196.title: IPC Section 174A: Non-appearance in response to a proclamation under section 82 of CrPC

197.text:
IPC Section 175: Intentionally omitting to produce a document to a public servant by a person legally bound to produce it

Description: Whoever, being legally bound to produce or deliver up any document to any public servant, intentionally omits to do so, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person is ordered by a court to produce a land deed as evidence but intentionally withholds it.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
197.title: IPC Section 175: Intentionally omitting to produce a document to a public servant by a person legally bound to produce it

198.text:
IPC Section 176: Intentionally omitting to give notice or information to a public servant by a person legally bound to give it

Description: Whoever, being legally bound to give any notice or information to a public servant, intentionally omits to do so, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person fails to report a fatal accident to the police as required by law.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
198.title: IPC Section 176: Intentionally omitting to give notice or information to a public servant by a person legally bound to give it

199.text:
IPC Section 177: Knowingly furnishing false information to a public servant

Description: Whoever, being legally bound to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, furnishes information which he knows to be false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Giving a false name and address to a police officer during an investigation.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
199.title: IPC Section 177: Knowingly furnishing false information to a public servant

200.text:
IPC Section 178: Refusing oath when duly required to take oath by a public servant

Description: Whoever refuses to bind himself by an oath to state the truth, when required to do so by a public servant legally competent to require such oath, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A witness in a court case refuses to swear an oath or make a solemn affirmation before testifying.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
200.title: IPC Section 178: Refusing oath when duly required to take oath by a public servant

201.text:
IPC Section 179: Being legally bound to state truth, but refusing to answer questions

Description: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth on any subject to any public servant, refuses to answer any question demanded of him by such public servant, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A witness in a police investigation refuses to answer questions about what they saw.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
201.title: IPC Section 179: Being legally bound to state truth, but refusing to answer questions

202.text:
IPC Section 180: Refusing to sign a statement made to a public servant

Description: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him when required to do so by a public servant legally competent to require that he sign it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person gives a written statement to the police but then refuses to sign it.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
202.title: IPC Section 180: Refusing to sign a statement made to a public servant

203.text:
IPC Section 181: Knowingly stating to a public servant on oath anything which is false

Description: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath to state the truth on any subject, states anything which is false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A witness gives false testimony under oath in a court proceeding (perjury).

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
203.title: IPC Section 181: Knowingly stating to a public servant on oath anything which is false

204.text:
IPC Section 182: False information, with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to the injury of another person

Description: Whoever gives false information to a public servant, intending to cause such public servant to use his lawful power to injure or annoy another person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Filing a false police complaint against an enemy to get them arrested.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
204.title: IPC Section 182: False information, with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to the injury of another person

205.text:
IPC Section 183: Resistance to the taking of property by the lawful authority of a public servant

Description: Whoever offers resistance to the lawful taking of any property by a public servant, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Physically preventing a bailiff from seizing property as per a court's attachment order.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
205.title: IPC Section 183: Resistance to the taking of property by the lawful authority of a public servant

206.text:
IPC Section 184: Obstructing sale of property offered for sale by authority of a public servant

Description: Whoever intentionally obstructs any sale of property made by a public servant in the execution of his duty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating a disturbance at a public auction conducted by a government official to prevent bidding.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
206.title: IPC Section 184: Obstructing sale of property offered for sale by authority of a public servant

207.text:
IPC Section 185: Illegally purchasing or bidding for property offered for sale by authority of a public servant

Description: Whoever, at a sale of property held by a public servant, purchases or bids for property that he is not legally entitled to purchase or bid for, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A government employee illegally bids for property being auctioned by their own department.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.
207.title: IPC Section 185: Illegally purchasing or bidding for property offered for sale by authority of a public servant

208.text:
IPC Section 186: Obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions

Description: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any public servant in the discharge of his public functions, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Blocking a police vehicle from reaching the scene of a crime.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
208.title: IPC Section 186: Obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions

209.text:
IPC Section 187: Omission to assist public servant when bound by law to give assistance

Description: Whoever, being bound by law to render assistance to any public servant in the execution of his public duty, intentionally omits to give such assistance, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person refuses to help a police officer catch a criminal when the officer lawfully demands their help.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.
209.title: IPC Section 187: Omission to assist public servant when bound by law to give assistance

210.text:
IPC Section 188: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant

Description: Whoever knowingly disobeys any order duly promulgated by a public servant, if such disobedience causes obstruction, annoyance or injury to any person lawfully employed, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Violating a curfew order imposed by a District Magistrate.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both. If such disobedience causes danger to human life, etc., imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
210.title: IPC Section 188: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant

211.text:
IPC Section 189: Threat of injury to public servant

Description: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to a public servant to induce him to do any act or to forbear from doing any act connected with his office, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening a tax officer to avoid a high tax assessment.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
211.title: IPC Section 189: Threat of injury to public servant

212.text:
IPC Section 190: Threat of injury to induce person to refrain from applying for protection to public servant

Description: Whoever holds out a threat of injury to any person to induce him to refrain from making a legal application to a public servant for protection from injury, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening a victim to prevent them from going to the police to file a complaint.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
212.title: IPC Section 190: Threat of injury to induce person to refrain from applying for protection to public servant

213.text:
IPC Section 191: Giving false evidence

Description: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.

Example Use Cases: A witness in court lies under oath about what they saw at a crime scene.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 193.
213.title: IPC Section 191: Giving false evidence

214.text:
IPC Section 192: Fabricating false evidence

Description: Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry or alters any document with the intention that it may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, and thereby cause a person to form an erroneous opinion on a material point, is said to fabricate false evidence.

Example Use Cases: Planting fake documents to mislead a court investigation.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 193.
214.title: IPC Section 192: Fabricating false evidence

215.text:
IPC Section 193: Punishment for false evidence

Description: Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Perjury in a murder trial.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If not in a judicial proceeding, imprisonment up to three years and fine.
215.title: IPC Section 193: Punishment for false evidence

216.text:
IPC Section 194: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of capital offence

Description: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence, intending thereby to cause any person to be convicted of an offence which is capital by law, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Framing someone for murder by giving false testimony.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
216.title: IPC Section 194: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of capital offence

217.text:
IPC Section 195: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of offence punishable with imprisonment for life

Description: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence intending to cause any person to be convicted of an offence which is punishable with imprisonment for life or imprisonment for seven years or more, shall be punished as if he had committed the offence.

Example Use Cases: Falsely testifying to get someone convicted for a crime that carries a life sentence.

Punishment: Punishment as for the offence they were trying to procure conviction for.
217.title: IPC Section 195: Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of offence punishable with imprisonment for life

218.text:
IPC Section 195A: Threatening any person to give false evidence

Description: Whoever threatens another with any injury to his person, property or reputation, to make that person give false evidence or fabricate false evidence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Threatening a witness to force them to lie in court.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
218.title: IPC Section 195A: Threatening any person to give false evidence

219.text:
IPC Section 196: Using evidence known to be false

Description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any evidence which he knows to be false or fabricated, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave or fabricated false evidence.

Example Use Cases: A lawyer knowingly presenting forged documents in court.

Punishment: Punishment as for giving or fabricating false evidence (Section 193).
219.title: IPC Section 196: Using evidence known to be false

220.text:
IPC Section 197: Issuing or signing false certificate

Description: Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, relating to any fact of which he is legally bound to report the truth, and which he knows to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

Example Use Cases: A doctor issuing a false medical certificate of fitness.

Punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).
220.title: IPC Section 197: Issuing or signing false certificate

221.text:
IPC Section 198: Using as true a certificate known to be false

Description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such certificate as a true certificate, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

Example Use Cases: Using a forged educational certificate to get a government job.

Punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).
221.title: IPC Section 198: Using as true a certificate known to be false

222.text:
IPC Section 199: False statement made in declaration which is by law receivable as evidence

Description: Whoever makes any false statement in any declaration which is by law receivable as evidence, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

Example Use Cases: Making a false statement in an affidavit submitted to court.

Punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).
222.title: IPC Section 199: False statement made in declaration which is by law receivable as evidence

223.text:
IPC Section 200: Using as true such declaration knowing it to be false

Description: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such declaration as true, knowing it to be false, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

Example Use Cases: Using a forged affidavit as evidence in a legal proceeding.

Punishment: Punishment as for giving false evidence (Section 193).
223.title: IPC Section 200: Using as true such declaration knowing it to be false

224.text:
IPC Section 201: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender

Description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, causes evidence to disappear or gives false information about the offence to screen the offender from legal punishment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Helping a murderer hide the murder weapon.

Punishment: If offence is capital: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine. If punishable with life imprisonment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. For any other offence: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
224.title: IPC Section 201: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender

225.text:
IPC Section 202: Intentional omission to give information of offence by person bound to inform

Description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, intentionally omits to give any information respecting that offence which he is legally bound to give, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A village headman fails to report a murder he knows about.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
225.title: IPC Section 202: Intentional omission to give information of offence by person bound to inform

226.text:
IPC Section 203: Giving false information respecting an offence committed

Description: Whoever, knowing or having reason to believe that an offence has been committed, gives any information respecting that offence which he knows or believes to be false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Providing a false alibi to the police for a suspect.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
226.title: IPC Section 203: Giving false information respecting an offence committed

227.text:
IPC Section 204: Destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence

Description: Whoever secretes or destroys any document which he may be lawfully compelled to produce as evidence, with intent to prevent its production, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Destroying a contract document that has been subpoenaed for a court case.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
227.title: IPC Section 204: Destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence

228.text:
IPC Section 205: False personation for purpose of act or proceeding in suit or prosecution

Description: Whoever falsely personates another, and in such assumed character makes any admission or statement, or confesses judgment, or causes any process to be issued, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Posing as someone else in court to confess to a crime they didn't commit.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
228.title: IPC Section 205: False personation for purpose of act or proceeding in suit or prosecution

229.text:
IPC Section 206: Fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution

Description: Whoever fraudulently removes, conceals, transfers or delivers to any person any property to prevent its seizure as a forfeiture or in execution of a decree, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Hiding assets to prevent them from being seized by court officials.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
229.title: IPC Section 206: Fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution

230.text:
IPC Section 207: Fraudulent claim to property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution

Description: Whoever fraudulently accepts, receives or claims any property to prevent its seizure as a forfeiture or in execution of a decree, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Falsely claiming ownership of property that is about to be seized by authorities.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
230.title: IPC Section 207: Fraudulent claim to property to prevent its seizure as forfeited or in execution

231.text:
IPC Section 208: Fraudulently suffering decree for sum not due

Description: Whoever fraudulently causes or suffers a decree to be passed against him for a sum not due, to damage or annoy any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Allowing a false court judgment against oneself to harm another's interests.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
231.title: IPC Section 208: Fraudulently suffering decree for sum not due

232.text:
IPC Section 209: Dishonestly making false claim in Court

Description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly makes a false claim in any Court of Justice, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Filing a false lawsuit claiming ownership of property that belongs to someone else.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
232.title: IPC Section 209: Dishonestly making false claim in Court

233.text:
IPC Section 210: Fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due

Description: Whoever fraudulently obtains a decree against any person for a sum not due, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using forged documents to obtain a court judgment in one's favor.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
233.title: IPC Section 210: Fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due

234.text:
IPC Section 211: False charge of offence made with intent to injure

Description: Whoever makes a false charge of any offence to a public servant, with intent to injure any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Filing a false police report accusing an innocent person of theft.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both. If offence is punishable with imprisonment for seven years or more: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
234.title: IPC Section 211: False charge of offence made with intent to injure

235.text:
IPC Section 212: Harbouring offender

Description: Whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to be an offender, to screen him from legal punishment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Hiding a fugitive from justice in one's home.

Punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to five years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to three years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
235.title: IPC Section 212: Harbouring offender

236.text:
IPC Section 213: Taking gift, etc., to screen an offender from punishment

Description: Whoever takes a gift or gratification to screen an offender from punishment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Accepting a bribe to not report a crime to the police.

Punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
236.title: IPC Section 213: Taking gift, etc., to screen an offender from punishment

237.text:
IPC Section 214: Offering gift or restoration of property in consideration of screening offender

Description: Whoever gives any gratification to screen an offender, or restores property to induce screening, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Paying money to a witness to not testify in court.

Punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-fourth of the maximum term for that offence.
237.title: IPC Section 214: Offering gift or restoration of property in consideration of screening offender

238.text:
IPC Section 215: Taking gift to help to recover stolen property, etc.

Description: Whoever takes a gift to help recover movable property of which a person has been deprived by an offence, without using lawful means, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person takes money to help recover stolen goods but has no intention of using legal channels.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
238.title: IPC Section 215: Taking gift to help to recover stolen property, etc.

239.text:
IPC Section 216: Harbouring offender who has escaped from custody or whose apprehension has been ordered

Description: Whoever harbours or conceals any person who has escaped from custody or for whose apprehension a warrant has been issued, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Sheltering a prisoner who has broken out of jail.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
239.title: IPC Section 216: Harbouring offender who has escaped from custody or whose apprehension has been ordered

240.text:
IPC Section 216A: Penalty for harbouring dacoits

Description: Whoever harbours members of a gang of dacoits, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Providing shelter and supplies to a known gang of dacoits.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
240.title: IPC Section 216A: Penalty for harbouring dacoits

241.text:
IPC Section 216B: [Repealed]

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
241.title: IPC Section 216B: [Repealed]

242.text:
IPC Section 217: Public servant disobeying direction of law with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, disobeys any direction of law with intent to save any person from legal punishment or any property from forfeiture, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer deliberately fails to arrest a known criminal.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
242.title: IPC Section 217: Public servant disobeying direction of law with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture

243.text:
IPC Section 218: Public servant framing incorrect record or writing with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, frames an incorrect record or writing with intent to save any person from legal punishment or any property from forfeiture, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer prepares a false report to help a guilty person avoid conviction.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
243.title: IPC Section 218: Public servant framing incorrect record or writing with intent to save person from punishment or property from forfeiture

244.text:
IPC Section 219: Public servant in judicial proceeding corruptly making report, etc., contrary to law

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, corruptly makes any report or gives any decision which he knows to be contrary to law, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A judge knowingly gives a wrong judgment in exchange for a bribe.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
244.title: IPC Section 219: Public servant in judicial proceeding corruptly making report, etc., contrary to law

245.text:
IPC Section 220: Commitment for trial or confinement by person having authority who knows that he is acting contrary to law

Description: Whoever, being in authority, corruptly or maliciously commits any person for trial or confinement knowing that such action is contrary to law, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A magistrate knowingly orders the detention of a person without legal grounds.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
245.title: IPC Section 220: Commitment for trial or confinement by person having authority who knows that he is acting contrary to law

246.text:
IPC Section 221: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend

Description: Whoever, being a public servant legally bound to apprehend or keep in confinement any person, intentionally omits to apprehend him or allows him to escape, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A prison guard deliberately lets a prisoner escape.

Punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to three years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to two years and fine.
246.title: IPC Section 221: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend

247.text:
IPC Section 222: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend person under sentence or lawfully committed

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, intentionally allows a person under sentence or lawfully committed to custody to escape, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer transporting a convict deliberately lets them go.

Punishment: If offence is capital: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine. For offence punishable with life imprisonment: imprisonment up to seven years and fine. For other offences: imprisonment up to one-half the maximum term for that offence.
247.title: IPC Section 222: Intentional omission to apprehend on the part of public servant bound to apprehend person under sentence or lawfully committed

248.text:
IPC Section 223: Escape from confinement or custody negligently suffered by public servant

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, negligently suffers any person in confinement to escape, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A jail guard falls asleep on duty, allowing a prisoner to escape.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
248.title: IPC Section 223: Escape from confinement or custody negligently suffered by public servant

249.text:
IPC Section 224: Resistance or obstruction by a person to his lawful apprehension

Description: Whoever offers resistance or illegal obstruction to the lawful apprehension of himself or any other person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A suspect physically fights with police officers trying to arrest him.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
249.title: IPC Section 224: Resistance or obstruction by a person to his lawful apprehension

250.text:
IPC Section 225: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of another person

Description: Whoever offers resistance or illegal obstruction to the lawful apprehension of any other person, or rescues or attempts to rescue any other person from lawful custody, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A mob attacks a police vehicle to free a arrested person.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both. If offence is punishable with death or life imprisonment: imprisonment up to eight years and fine.
250.title: IPC Section 225: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension of another person

251.text:
IPC Section 225A: Omission to apprehend, or sufferance of escape, on part of public servant, in cases not otherwise provided for

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, illegally omits to apprehend or suffers to escape any person, in cases not otherwise provided for, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A public servant's negligent conduct leads to the escape of a person in a situation not covered by other sections.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
251.title: IPC Section 225A: Omission to apprehend, or sufferance of escape, on part of public servant, in cases not otherwise provided for

252.text:
IPC Section 225B: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension, or escape or rescue in cases not otherwise provided for

Description: Whoever resists lawful apprehension, or escapes from custody, in cases not otherwise provided for, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Resisting arrest in a situation not covered by more specific sections.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
252.title: IPC Section 225B: Resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension, or escape or rescue in cases not otherwise provided for

253.text:
IPC Section 226: [Repealed]

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

Punishment: [Repealed]
253.title: IPC Section 226: [Repealed]

254.text:
IPC Section 227: Violation of condition of remission of punishment

Description: Whoever, having accepted any conditional remission of punishment, violates any condition, shall be punished with the punishment of the original offence.

Example Use Cases: A prisoner released early on parole breaks the terms of their parole.

Punishment: Punishment for the original offence.
254.title: IPC Section 227: Violation of condition of remission of punishment

255.text:
IPC Section 228: Intentional insult or interruption to public servant sitting in judicial proceeding

Description: Whoever intentionally offers any insult or causes any interruption to any public servant while such public servant is sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Shouting insults at a judge during a court hearing.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
255.title: IPC Section 228: Intentional insult or interruption to public servant sitting in judicial proceeding

256.text:
IPC Section 228A: Disclosure of identity of the victim of certain offences etc.

Description: Whoever prints or publishes the name or any matter which may make known the identity of any person against whom certain sexual offences have been committed, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A newspaper reveals the name of a rape victim.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
256.title: IPC Section 228A: Disclosure of identity of the victim of certain offences etc.

257.text:
IPC Section 229: Personation of a juror or assessor

Description: Whoever, by personation or otherwise, intentionally causes himself to be served with a summons as a juror or assessor, or serves on such jury or as such assessor, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Posing as someone else to serve on a jury.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
257.title: IPC Section 229: Personation of a juror or assessor

258.text:
IPC Section 229A: Failure by person released on bail or bond to appear in Court

Description: Whoever, having been charged with an offence and released on bail or bond, fails without sufficient cause to appear in court, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person jumps bail and does not show up for their court date.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. If the offence is non-bailable, punishment for the original offence may also be applied.
258.title: IPC Section 229A: Failure by person released on bail or bond to appear in Court

259.text:
IPC Section 230: 'Coin' defined

Description: Coin is defined as metal used for the time being as money, and stamped and issued by the authority of some State or Sovereign Power in order to be so used.

Example Use Cases: Indian rupee coins, US dollar coins, or British pound coins.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
259.title: IPC Section 230: 'Coin' defined

260.text:
IPC Section 231: Counterfeiting coin

Description: Whoever counterfeits or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Manufacturing fake Indian rupee coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
260.title: IPC Section 231: Counterfeiting coin

261.text:
IPC Section 232: Counterfeiting Indian coin

Description: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, Indian coin, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.

Example Use Cases: Manufacturing fake Indian currency coins with intent to circulate them.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
261.title: IPC Section 232: Counterfeiting Indian coin

262.text:
IPC Section 233: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting coin

Description: Whoever makes, mends, buys, sells, or disposes of any die or instrument for the purpose of being used in counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling equipment designed to mint counterfeit coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
262.title: IPC Section 233: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting coin

263.text:
IPC Section 234: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Indian coin

Description: Whoever makes, mends, buys, sells, or disposes of any die or instrument for the purpose of being used in counterfeiting Indian coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating a mold specifically designed to counterfeit Indian rupee coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
263.title: IPC Section 234: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Indian coin

264.text:
IPC Section 235: Possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting coin

Description: Whoever is in possession of any instrument or material for the purpose of using it in counterfeiting coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being found with blank metal discs and dyes intended for making fake coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If for Indian coin: imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
264.title: IPC Section 235: Possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting coin

265.text:
IPC Section 236: Abetting in India the counterfeiting out of India of coin

Description: Whoever, being within India, abets the counterfeiting of coin outside India, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person in India provides designs to someone abroad to counterfeit foreign currency.

Punishment: Punishment as for counterfeiting such coin.
265.title: IPC Section 236: Abetting in India the counterfeiting out of India of coin

266.text:
IPC Section 237: Import or export of counterfeit coin

Description: Whoever imports into India, or exports therefrom, any counterfeit coin, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Smuggling fake US dollar coins into India.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
266.title: IPC Section 237: Import or export of counterfeit coin

267.text:
IPC Section 238: Import or export of counterfeits of the Indian coin

Description: Whoever imports into India, or exports therefrom, any counterfeit Indian coin, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Smuggling fake Indian rupee coins into or out of the country.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
267.title: IPC Section 238: Import or export of counterfeits of the Indian coin

268.text:
IPC Section 239: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit

Description: Whoever, having any counterfeit coin which he knows to be counterfeit, delivers it to another person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Paying for goods with counterfeit coins knowing they are fake.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.
268.title: IPC Section 239: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit

269.text:
IPC Section 240: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit

Description: Whoever, having any counterfeit Indian coin which he knows to be counterfeit, delivers it to another person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using fake Indian rupee coins to make a purchase.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
269.title: IPC Section 240: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is counterfeit

270.text:
IPC Section 241: Delivery of coin as genuine, which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be counterfeit

Description: Whoever delivers to another any counterfeit coin as genuine, which he did not know to be counterfeit when he took it into his possession, but subsequently discovered to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A shopkeeper receives a counterfeit coin as change and, upon realizing it is fake, uses it to pay another customer.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine up to ten times the value of the coin, or both.
270.title: IPC Section 241: Delivery of coin as genuine, which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be counterfeit

271.text:
IPC Section 242: Possession of counterfeit coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof

Description: Whoever, with knowledge that a coin is counterfeit, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Holding onto counterfeit coins with the intent to use them later.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
271.title: IPC Section 242: Possession of counterfeit coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof

272.text:
IPC Section 243: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof

Description: Whoever, with knowledge that an Indian coin is counterfeit, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being in possession of fake Indian rupee coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
272.title: IPC Section 243: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be counterfeit when he became possessed thereof

273.text:
IPC Section 244: Person employed in mint causing coin to be of different weight or composition from that fixed by law

Description: Whoever, being employed in a mint, causes a coin to be of a different weight or composition than that established by law, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A mint worker deliberately produces coins with less metal content than required.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
273.title: IPC Section 244: Person employed in mint causing coin to be of different weight or composition from that fixed by law

274.text:
IPC Section 245: Unlawfully taking from mint any coining instrument

Description: Whoever, without lawful authority, takes from a mint any tool or instrument used for coining, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Stealing a dye or press from the government mint.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
274.title: IPC Section 245: Unlawfully taking from mint any coining instrument

275.text:
IPC Section 246: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of coin

Description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly diminishes the weight or alters the composition of any coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Shaving off bits of metal from coins to sell the metal.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
275.title: IPC Section 246: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of coin

276.text:
IPC Section 247: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of Indian coin

Description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly diminishes the weight or alters the composition of any Indian coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Altering the composition of an Indian rupee coin.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
276.title: IPC Section 247: Fraudulently or dishonestly diminishing weight or altering composition of Indian coin

277.text:
IPC Section 248: Altering appearance of coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description

Description: Whoever alters the appearance of any coin with the intent that it shall pass as a coin of a different description, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Plating a low-value coin with gold to make it resemble a high-value coin.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
277.title: IPC Section 248: Altering appearance of coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description

278.text:
IPC Section 249: Altering appearance of Indian coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description

Description: Whoever alters the appearance of any Indian coin with the intent that it shall pass as a coin of a different description, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Altering a ₹5 coin to make it look like a ₹10 coin.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
278.title: IPC Section 249: Altering appearance of Indian coin with intent that it shall pass as coin of different description

279.text:
IPC Section 250: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered

Description: Whoever, having a coin whose weight or composition has been altered, delivers it to another person, knowing it to be altered, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using a coin that has been shaved down to make a purchase.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.
279.title: IPC Section 250: Delivery of coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered

280.text:
IPC Section 251: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered

Description: Whoever, having an Indian coin whose weight or composition has been altered, delivers it to another person, knowing it to be altered, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Paying with an altered Indian rupee coin.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
280.title: IPC Section 251: Delivery of Indian coin, possessed with knowledge that it is altered

281.text:
IPC Section 252: Possession of coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof

Description: Whoever, with knowledge that a coin has been altered, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Holding onto coins that have been fraudulently diminished in weight.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
281.title: IPC Section 252: Possession of coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof

282.text:
IPC Section 253: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof

Description: Whoever, with knowledge that an Indian coin has been altered, is in possession of such coin, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being in possession of altered Indian rupee coins.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.
282.title: IPC Section 253: Possession of Indian coin by person who knew it to be altered when he became possessed thereof

283.text:
IPC Section 254: Delivery of coin as genuine which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be altered

Description: Whoever delivers to another an altered coin as genuine, which he did not know to be altered when he took it into his possession, but subsequently discovered to be altered, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person receives an altered coin as change and, after realizing it, uses it to pay someone else.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine up to ten times the value of the coin, or both.
283.title: IPC Section 254: Delivery of coin as genuine which, when first possessed, the deliverer did not know to be altered

284.text:
IPC Section 255: Counterfeiting Government stamp

Description: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Manufacturing fake court fee stamps or revenue stamps.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
284.title: IPC Section 255: Counterfeiting Government stamp

285.text:
IPC Section 256: Having possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting Government stamp

Description: Whoever has in his possession any instrument or material for the purpose of counterfeiting any Government stamp, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Possessing paper, ink, or plates specifically designed to create fake revenue stamps.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
285.title: IPC Section 256: Having possession of instrument or material for counterfeiting Government stamp

286.text:
IPC Section 257: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Government stamp

Description: Whoever makes, performs any part of the process of making, buys, sells, or disposes of any instrument for the purpose of counterfeiting any Government stamp, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling a printing press designed to create counterfeit government stamps.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
286.title: IPC Section 257: Making or selling instrument for counterfeiting Government stamp

287.text:
IPC Section 258: Sale of counterfeit Government stamp

Description: Whoever sells, or offers for sale, any counterfeit Government stamp, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling fake court fee stamps.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
287.title: IPC Section 258: Sale of counterfeit Government stamp

288.text:
IPC Section 259: Having possession of counterfeit Government stamp

Description: Whoever has in his possession any counterfeit Government stamp, knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Holding a quantity of counterfeit revenue stamps.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
288.title: IPC Section 259: Having possession of counterfeit Government stamp

289.text:
IPC Section 260: Using as genuine a Government stamp known to be counterfeit

Description: Whoever uses as genuine any Government stamp known to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Affixing a fake court fee stamp to a legal document.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
289.title: IPC Section 260: Using as genuine a Government stamp known to be counterfeit

290.text:
IPC Section 261: Effacing writing from substance bearing Government stamp, or removing from document a stamp used for it, with intent to cause loss to Government

Description: Whoever, with intent to cause loss to Government, effaces any writing from a substance bearing a Government stamp, or removes from a document a stamp that has been used for it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Removing a used revenue stamp from one document to reuse it on another.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
290.title: IPC Section 261: Effacing writing from substance bearing Government stamp, or removing from document a stamp used for it, with intent to cause loss to Government

291.text:
IPC Section 262: Using Government stamp known to have been before used

Description: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to Government, uses any Government stamp which has been before used, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Reusing a postage stamp or revenue stamp that has already been canceled.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
291.title: IPC Section 262: Using Government stamp known to have been before used

292.text:
IPC Section 263: Erasure of mark denoting that stamp has been used

Description: Whoever erases or removes any mark indicating that a stamp has been used, with intent to use it again, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Removing the cancellation mark from a used postage stamp.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
292.title: IPC Section 263: Erasure of mark denoting that stamp has been used

293.text:
IPC Section 263A: Prohibition of fictitious stamps

Description: (1) Whoever makes, sells, or uses any fictitious stamp, or knowingly has in his possession any fictitious stamp, shall be punished. (2) A fictitious stamp means any stamp that resembles a Government stamp but is not issued by the Government.

Example Use Cases: Producing or selling fake postage stamps that look like real ones.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
293.title: IPC Section 263A: Prohibition of fictitious stamps

294.text:
IPC Section 264: Fraudulent use of false instrument for weighing

Description: Whoever fraudulently uses any instrument for weighing which he knows to be false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A shopkeeper uses a rigged weighing scale to cheat customers.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
294.title: IPC Section 264: Fraudulent use of false instrument for weighing

295.text:
IPC Section 265: Fraudulent use of false weight or measure

Description: Whoever fraudulently uses any false weight or false measure of length or capacity, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using a shortened measuring tape or underweight weights in trade.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
295.title: IPC Section 265: Fraudulent use of false weight or measure

296.text:
IPC Section 266: Being in possession of false weight or measure

Description: Whoever is in possession of any false weight or measure, knowing it to be false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A merchant keeps altered weights in his shop intending to use them.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
296.title: IPC Section 266: Being in possession of false weight or measure

297.text:
IPC Section 267: Making or selling false weight or measure

Description: Whoever makes, sells, or disposes of any weight or measure which he knows to be false, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Manufacturing and selling rigged weighing scales.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
297.title: IPC Section 267: Making or selling false weight or measure

298.text:
IPC Section 268: Public nuisance

Description: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public or to the people in general who dwell or occupy property in the vicinity.

Example Use Cases: Blocking a public road, causing loud noise at night, or polluting a public water source.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 290.
298.title: IPC Section 268: Public nuisance

299.text:
IPC Section 269: Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life

Description: Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person with a contagious disease knowingly travels in a crowded bus.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
299.title: IPC Section 269: Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life

300.text:
IPC Section 270: Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
