Description: Whoever malignantly does any act which is likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Intentionally spreading a dangerous disease by contaminating food or water.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
300.title: IPC Section 270: Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life

301.text:
IPC Section 271: Disobedience to quarantine rule

Description: Whoever knowingly disobeys any rule made and promulgated by the Government for putting any vessel into a state of quarantine, or for regulating the intercourse of such vessel with the shore, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A ship captain ignores quarantine protocols during an outbreak.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
301.title: IPC Section 271: Disobedience to quarantine rule

302.text:
IPC Section 272: Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale

Description: Whoever adulterates any article of food or drink, so as to make such article noxious as food or drink, intending to sell it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Mixing water with milk or adding harmful chemicals to food products for sale.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
302.title: IPC Section 272: Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale

303.text:
IPC Section 273: Sale of noxious food or drink

Description: Whoever sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any article of food or drink which he knows to be noxious, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling spoiled meat or contaminated beverages.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
303.title: IPC Section 273: Sale of noxious food or drink

304.text:
IPC Section 274: Adulteration of drugs

Description: Whoever adulterates any drug or medical preparation so as to lessen its efficacy or to make it noxious, intending to sell it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Diluting medicine with inactive ingredients to increase quantity.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
304.title: IPC Section 274: Adulteration of drugs

305.text:
IPC Section 275: Sale of adulterated drugs

Description: Whoever sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any drug or medical preparation which he knows to be adulterated, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling diluted or fake medicines.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
305.title: IPC Section 275: Sale of adulterated drugs

306.text:
IPC Section 276: Sale of drug as a different drug or preparation

Description: Whoever knowingly sells, or offers or exposes for sale, any drug or medical preparation as a different drug or preparation, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling a cheap medicine as an expensive branded drug.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
306.title: IPC Section 276: Sale of drug as a different drug or preparation

307.text:
IPC Section 277: Fouling water of public spring or reservoir

Description: Whoever voluntarily corrupts or fouls the water of any public spring or reservoir, so as to render it less fit for the purpose for which it is ordinarily used, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Dumping industrial waste into a public water source.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
307.title: IPC Section 277: Fouling water of public spring or reservoir

308.text:
IPC Section 278: Making atmosphere noxious to health

Description: Whoever voluntarily vitiates the atmosphere in any place so as to make it noxious to the health of persons in general dwelling or carrying on business in the neighbourhood, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Releasing toxic fumes from a factory in a residential area.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five hundred rupees.
308.title: IPC Section 278: Making atmosphere noxious to health

309.text:
IPC Section 279: Rash driving or riding on a public way

Description: Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides, on any public way in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Driving a car at high speed in a crowded market area.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
309.title: IPC Section 279: Rash driving or riding on a public way

310.text:
IPC Section 280: Rash navigation of vessel

Description: Whoever navigates any vessel in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Operating a boat in a reckless manner in a crowded waterway.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
310.title: IPC Section 280: Rash navigation of vessel

311.text:
IPC Section 281: Exhibition of false light, mark or buoy

Description: Whoever exhibits any false light, mark or buoy, intending that such exhibition may mislead any navigator, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Setting up a fake lighthouse signal that causes a ship to run aground.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
311.title: IPC Section 281: Exhibition of false light, mark or buoy

312.text:
IPC Section 282: Conveying person by water for hire in unsafe or overloaded vessel

Description: Whoever knowingly or negligently conveys, or causes to be conveyed, any person by water in any vessel, when that vessel is in such a state or so loaded as to endanger the life of that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A ferry operator overloads his boat with passengers.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
312.title: IPC Section 282: Conveying person by water for hire in unsafe or overloaded vessel

313.text:
IPC Section 283: Danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation

Description: Whoever, by doing any act, or by omitting to take order with any property in his possession or under his charge, causes danger, obstruction or injury to any person in any public way or line of navigation, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Leaving construction materials blocking a sidewalk or road.

Punishment: Fine up to two hundred rupees.
313.title: IPC Section 283: Danger or obstruction in public way or line of navigation

314.text:
IPC Section 284: Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance

Description: Whoever does, with any poisonous substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Leaving poisonous pesticides open and accessible to children.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
314.title: IPC Section 284: Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substance

315.text:
IPC Section 285: Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter

Description: Whoever does, with fire or any combustible matter, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Carelessly storing gasoline near a source of heat.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
315.title: IPC Section 285: Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter

316.text:
IPC Section 286: Negligent conduct with respect to explosive substance

Description: Whoever does, with any explosive substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Handling fireworks negligently in a crowded area.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
316.title: IPC Section 286: Negligent conduct with respect to explosive substance

317.text:
IPC Section 287: Negligent conduct with respect to machinery

Description: Whoever does, with any machinery, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Operating industrial equipment without safety guards.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
317.title: IPC Section 287: Negligent conduct with respect to machinery

318.text:
IPC Section 288: Negligent conduct with respect to pulling down or repairing buildings

Description: Whoever, in pulling down or repairing any building, knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with that building as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life from the fall of that building or of any part thereof, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Failing to put up safety nets during building demolition.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
318.title: IPC Section 288: Negligent conduct with respect to pulling down or repairing buildings

319.text:
IPC Section 289: Negligent conduct with respect to animal

Description: Whoever knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with any animal in his possession as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life, or any probable danger of grievous hurt from such animal, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Allowing a dangerous dog to roam freely in a public park.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
319.title: IPC Section 289: Negligent conduct with respect to animal

320.text:
IPC Section 290: Punishment for public nuisance in cases not otherwise provided for

Description: Whoever commits a public nuisance in any case not otherwise punishable by this Code, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating excessive smoke or noise that annoys the public.

Punishment: Fine up to two hundred rupees.
320.title: IPC Section 290: Punishment for public nuisance in cases not otherwise provided for

321.text:
IPC Section 291: Continuance of nuisance after injunction to discontinue

Description: Whoever repeats or continues a public nuisance, having been enjoined by any public servant who has lawful authority to issue such injunction not to repeat or continue such nuisance, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Continuing to play loud music after being warned by the police to stop.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
321.title: IPC Section 291: Continuance of nuisance after injunction to discontinue

322.text:
IPC Section 292: Sale, etc., of obscene books, etc.

Description: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, publicly exhibits or in any manner puts into circulation, any obscene book, pamphlet, paper, drawing, painting, representation or figure or any other obscene object, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling or distributing pornography.

Punishment: First conviction: imprisonment up to two years and fine up to two thousand rupees. Subsequent conviction: imprisonment up to five years and fine up to five thousand rupees.
322.title: IPC Section 292: Sale, etc., of obscene books, etc.

323.text:
IPC Section 293: Sale, etc., of obscene objects to young person

Description: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, exhibits or circulates any obscene object to any person under the age of twenty years, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling pornographic material to a minor.

Punishment: First conviction: imprisonment up to three years and fine up to two thousand rupees. Subsequent conviction: imprisonment up to seven years and fine up to five thousand rupees.
323.title: IPC Section 293: Sale, etc., of obscene objects to young person

324.text:
IPC Section 294: Obscene acts and songs

Description: Whoever, to the annoyance of others, does any obscene act in any public place, or sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words in or near any public place, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using lewd language or performing indecent acts in a public place.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine, or both.
324.title: IPC Section 294: Obscene acts and songs

325.text:
IPC Section 294A: Keeping lottery office

Description: Whoever keeps any office or place for the purpose of drawing any lottery not being a State lottery or a lottery authorized by the State Government, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Operating an illegal gambling or lottery house.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine, or both.
325.title: IPC Section 294A: Keeping lottery office

326.text:
IPC Section 295: Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class

Description: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship, or any object held sacred by any class of persons, with the intention of thereby insulting the religion of any class of persons, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Vandalizing a temple, mosque, church, or gurdwara.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
326.title: IPC Section 295: Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class

327.text:
IPC Section 295A: Deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs

Description: Whoever, with deliberate and malicious intention of outraging the religious feelings of any class of citizens, insults or attempts to insult the religion or the religious beliefs of that class, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating and sharing content online that deeply insults a religious community.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
327.title: IPC Section 295A: Deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs

328.text:
IPC Section 296: Disturbing religious assembly

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship, or religious ceremonies, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Disrupting a prayer meeting or a religious procession with loud noise.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
328.title: IPC Section 296: Disturbing religious assembly

329.text:
IPC Section 297: Trespassing on burial places, etc.

Description: Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, commits any trespass in any place of worship or on any place of sepulchre, or any place set apart for the performance of funeral rites, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Desecrating a grave or a cremation ground.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
329.title: IPC Section 297: Trespassing on burial places, etc.

330.text:
IPC Section 298: Uttering words, etc., with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings

Description: Whoever, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of any person, utters any word or makes any sound in the hearing of that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Making derogatory remarks about a person's deity or prophet.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
330.title: IPC Section 298: Uttering words, etc., with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings

331.text:
IPC Section 299: Culpable homicide

Description: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

Example Use Cases: A person attacks another with a weapon, not necessarily intending to kill but knowing the act is likely to cause death.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 304.
331.title: IPC Section 299: Culpable homicide

332.text:
IPC Section 300: Murder

Description: Except in the cases of exceptions, culpable homicide is murder if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or if it is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or if it is done with the intention of causing bodily injury to any person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or if the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death.

Example Use Cases: Intentionally shooting someone in the head; stabbing someone in the heart.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 302.
332.title: IPC Section 300: Murder

333.text:
IPC Section 301: Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than person whose death was intended

Description: If a person, by doing anything which he intends or knows to be likely to cause death, commits culpable homicide by causing the death of any person, whose death he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause, the culpable homicide committed by the offender is of the description of which it would have been if he had caused the death of the person whose death he intended or knew himself to be likely to cause.

Example Use Cases: A intends to kill B but misses and kills C instead. A is guilty of the murder of C.

Punishment: Punishment for the offence as if the intended person had been killed.
333.title: IPC Section 301: Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than person whose death was intended

334.text:
IPC Section 302: Punishment for murder

Description: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Premeditated killing; killing during a robbery.

Punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine.
334.title: IPC Section 302: Punishment for murder

335.text:
IPC Section 303: Punishment for murder by life-convict

Description: Whoever, being under sentence of imprisonment for life, commits murder, shall be punished with death.

Example Use Cases: A person already serving a life sentence kills another inmate or a prison guard.

Punishment: Death.
335.title: IPC Section 303: Punishment for murder by life-convict

336.text:
IPC Section 304: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder

Description: Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine, if the act is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death; or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both, if the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death.

Example Use Cases: A death caused in a sudden fight without premeditation; a death caused by a negligent act that falls short of murder.

Punishment: If intentional: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine. If with knowledge but no intention: imprisonment up to ten years, or fine, or both.
336.title: IPC Section 304: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder

337.text:
IPC Section 304A: Causing death by negligence

Description: Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Death caused by rash driving; medical negligence during surgery.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
337.title: IPC Section 304A: Causing death by negligence

338.text:
IPC Section 304B: Dowry death

Description: Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry, such death shall be called "dowry death".

Example Use Cases: A woman is found dead in her matrimonial home within a few years of marriage, with evidence of ongoing harassment for dowry.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than seven years but which may extend to imprisonment for life.
338.title: IPC Section 304B: Dowry death

339.text:
IPC Section 305: Abetment of suicide of child or insane person

Description: If any person under eighteen years of age, any insane person, any delirious person, any idiot, or any person in a state of intoxication, commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Encouraging or helping a minor to commit suicide.

Punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
339.title: IPC Section 305: Abetment of suicide of child or insane person

340.text:
IPC Section 306: Abetment of suicide

Description: If any person commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Relentless bullying or harassment that drives a person to take their own life.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
340.title: IPC Section 306: Abetment of suicide

341.text:
IPC Section 307: Attempt to murder

Description: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances, that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Shooting at someone but missing; administering a non-lethal dose of poison.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine. If hurt is caused: imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine.
341.title: IPC Section 307: Attempt to murder

342.text:
IPC Section 308: Attempt to commit culpable homicide

Description: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: An attack that is likely to cause death but is not done with the specific intention to murder.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If hurt is caused: imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
342.title: IPC Section 308: Attempt to commit culpable homicide

343.text:
IPC Section 309: Attempt to commit suicide

Description: Whoever attempts to commit suicide and does any act towards the commission of such offence, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A person survives a suicide attempt.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both. (Note: This section is widely read down and not actively enforced in many jurisdictions)
343.title: IPC Section 309: Attempt to commit suicide

344.text:
IPC Section 310: Thug

Description: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied with murder, is a thug.

Example Use Cases: Being part of a gang that murders people to rob them.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 311.
344.title: IPC Section 310: Thug

345.text:
IPC Section 311: Punishment

Description: Whoever is a thug, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: A member of a gang that operates as thugs.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine.
345.title: IPC Section 311: Punishment

346.text:
IPC Section 312: Causing miscarriage

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall be punished. If the woman is quick with child, the punishment is higher.

Example Use Cases: A person administers drugs to a pregnant woman to terminate her pregnancy without her consent or medical justification.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both. If quick with child: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
346.title: IPC Section 312: Causing miscarriage

347.text:
IPC Section 313: Causing miscarriage without woman's consent

Description: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section without the consent of the woman, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Forcibly causing a woman to miscarry against her will.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
347.title: IPC Section 313: Causing miscarriage without woman's consent

348.text:
IPC Section 314: Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage

Description: Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A botched illegal abortion procedure that results in the death of the woman.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
348.title: IPC Section 314: Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage

349.text:
IPC Section 315: Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth

Description: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of preventing that child from being born alive or causing it to die after its birth, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Injuring a pregnant woman to cause the death of the fetus or newborn child.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years, or fine, or both.
349.title: IPC Section 315: Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth

350.text:
IPC Section 316: Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

Description: Whoever does any act under such circumstances that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A violent assault on a pregnant woman that kills her viable fetus.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
350.title: IPC Section 316: Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

351.text:
IPC Section 317: Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years, by parent or person having care of it

Description: Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, exposes or leaves such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Leaving a newborn baby in a garbage dump.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
351.title: IPC Section 317: Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years, by parent or person having care of it

352.text:
IPC Section 318: Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body

Description: Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child, whether such child dies before or after or during its birth, intentionally conceals or endeavours to conceal the birth of such child, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Burying a stillborn child in a backyard to hide the pregnancy.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
352.title: IPC Section 318: Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body

353.text:
IPC Section 319: Hurt

Description: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.

Example Use Cases: Slapping someone, pushing them, or causing them to become ill.

Punishment: Punishment as per subsequent sections.
353.title: IPC Section 319: Hurt

354.text:
IPC Section 320: Grievous hurt

Description: The following kinds of hurt only are designated as "grievous": Emasculation; Permanent privation of the sight of either eye; Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear; Privation of any member or joint; Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint; Permanent disfiguration of the head or face; Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth; Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be during the space of twenty days in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.

Example Use Cases: Blinding someone in one eye; breaking a leg; causing a permanent facial scar.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 325.
354.title: IPC Section 320: Grievous hurt

355.text:
IPC Section 321: Voluntarily causing hurt

Description: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person, or with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause hurt to any person, and thereby causes hurt to any person, is said "voluntarily to cause hurt".

Example Use Cases: Intentionally punching someone and causing them pain.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 323.
355.title: IPC Section 321: Voluntarily causing hurt

356.text:
IPC Section 322: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt which he intends to cause or knows himself to be likely to cause is grievous hurt, is said "voluntarily to cause grievous hurt".

Example Use Cases: Intentionally attacking someone with a weapon, knowing it is likely to cause serious injury.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 325.
356.title: IPC Section 322: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt

357.text:
IPC Section 323: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt

Description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A fistfight where one person injures another.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
357.title: IPC Section 323: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt

358.text:
IPC Section 324: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means

Description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Stabbing someone with a knife; throwing acid; setting someone on fire.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
358.title: IPC Section 324: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means

359.text:
IPC Section 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: An attack that results in a broken bone or the loss of an eye.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
359.title: IPC Section 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt

360.text:
IPC Section 326: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means

Description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: An acid attack that causes permanent disfigurement; a shooting that causes a permanent injury.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
360.title: IPC Section 326: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means

361.text:
IPC Section 326A: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid

Description: Whoever causes permanent or partial damage or deformity to, or burns or maims or disfigures or disables, any part or parts of the body of a person, or causes grievous hurt by throwing acid on or administering acid to that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Throwing acid on a person's face, causing severe burns and blindness.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and fine.
361.title: IPC Section 326A: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid

362.text:
IPC Section 326B: Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid

Description: Whoever throws or attempts to throw acid on any person with the intention of causing permanent or partial damage or deformity or burns or maiming or disfigurement or disability or grievous hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Attempting to throw acid on someone but missing or being prevented.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to seven years, and fine.
362.title: IPC Section 326B: Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid

363.text:
IPC Section 327: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort property, or to constrain to an illegal act

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt for the purpose of extorting any property or valuable security, or of constraining any person to do anything which is illegal or which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Torturing someone to force them to sign over property.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
363.title: IPC Section 327: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort property, or to constrain to an illegal act

364.text:
IPC Section 328: Causing hurt by means of poison, etc., with intent to commit an offence

Description: Whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person any poison or any stupefying, intoxicating or unwholesome drug, or other thing with intent to cause hurt to such person, or to commit or facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Drugging someone's drink to rob them or to commit a sexual assault.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
364.title: IPC Section 328: Causing hurt by means of poison, etc., with intent to commit an offence

365.text:
IPC Section 329: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort property, or to constrain to an illegal act

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt for the purpose of extorting any property or valuable security, or of constraining any person to do anything which is illegal or which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Breaking someone's fingers to force them to reveal the combination of a safe.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
365.title: IPC Section 329: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort property, or to constrain to an illegal act

366.text:
IPC Section 330: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer torturing a suspect to extract a confession.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
366.title: IPC Section 330: Voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

367.text:
IPC Section 331: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer any confession or any information, or for the purpose of constraining the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Severely torturing someone to force them to return stolen property.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
367.title: IPC Section 331: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

368.text:
IPC Section 332: Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Assaulting a traffic police officer who is issuing a ticket.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
368.title: IPC Section 332: Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty

369.text:
IPC Section 333: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant from his duty

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing a serious injury to a police officer to prevent an arrest.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
369.title: IPC Section 333: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant from his duty

370.text:
IPC Section 334: Voluntarily causing hurt on provocation

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt on grave and sudden provocation, if he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause hurt to any person other than the person who gave the provocation, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person punches another in a fit of rage after being suddenly and severely insulted.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
370.title: IPC Section 334: Voluntarily causing hurt on provocation

371.text:
IPC Section 335: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt on provocation

Description: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt on grave and sudden provocation, if he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause grievous hurt to any person other than the person who gave the provocation, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing a serious injury in the heat of passion after a grave and sudden fight.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to four years, or fine up to two thousand rupees, or both.
371.title: IPC Section 335: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt on provocation

372.text:
IPC Section 336: Act endangering life or personal safety of others

Description: Whoever does any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Swinging a weapon carelessly in a crowded area.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to two hundred fifty rupees, or both.
372.title: IPC Section 336: Act endangering life or personal safety of others

373.text:
IPC Section 337: Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others

Description: Whoever causes hurt to any person by doing any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A car accident caused by rash driving that results in injuries.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to six months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
373.title: IPC Section 337: Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others

374.text:
IPC Section 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others

Description: Whoever causes grievous hurt to any person by doing any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A construction accident caused by negligence that results in a worker suffering a permanent disability.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
374.title: IPC Section 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others

375.text:
IPC Section 339: Wrongful restraint

Description: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any person so as to prevent that person from proceeding in any direction in which that person has a right to proceed, is said wrongfully to restrain that person.

Example Use Cases: Blocking someone's path on a public street to prevent them from moving forward.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 341.
375.title: IPC Section 339: Wrongful restraint

376.text:
IPC Section 340: Wrongful confinement

Description: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person in such a manner as to prevent that person from proceeding beyond certain circumscribing limits, is said "wrongfully to confine" that person.

Example Use Cases: Locking someone in a room against their will.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 342.
376.title: IPC Section 340: Wrongful confinement

377.text:
IPC Section 341: Punishment for wrongful restraint

Description: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Preventing someone from leaving a room by standing in front of the door.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
377.title: IPC Section 341: Punishment for wrongful restraint

378.text:
IPC Section 342: Punishment for wrongful confinement

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Kidnapping someone and keeping them tied up in a basement.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
378.title: IPC Section 342: Punishment for wrongful confinement

379.text:
IPC Section 343: Wrongful confinement for three or more days

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for three days or more, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Holding a person captive for several days.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
379.title: IPC Section 343: Wrongful confinement for three or more days

380.text:
IPC Section 344: Wrongful confinement for ten or more days

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for ten days or more, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Keeping someone imprisoned for a prolonged period.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, and fine.
380.title: IPC Section 344: Wrongful confinement for ten or more days

381.text:
IPC Section 345: Wrongful confinement of person for whose liberation writ has been issued

Description: Whoever keeps any person in wrongful confinement, knowing that a writ for the liberation of that person has been duly issued, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Ignoring a court order (habeas corpus) to release a detained person.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years in addition to the punishment under Section 344.
381.title: IPC Section 345: Wrongful confinement of person for whose liberation writ has been issued

382.text:
IPC Section 346: Wrongful confinement in secret

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person in such manner as to indicate an intention that the confinement of such person may not be known to any person interested in the person so confined, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Secretly holding someone captive in a hidden location.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years in addition to the punishment for the wrongful confinement.
382.title: IPC Section 346: Wrongful confinement in secret

383.text:
IPC Section 347: Wrongful confinement to extort property, or to constrain to illegal act

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting any property or valuable security, or of constraining the person confined to do anything illegal or to give any information to facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Kidnapping someone and demanding a ransom for their release.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
383.title: IPC Section 347: Wrongful confinement to extort property, or to constrain to illegal act

384.text:
IPC Section 348: Wrongful confinement to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

Description: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting from the person confined or any person interested in the person confined any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the person confined to restore or cause the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Imprisoning someone to force them to confess to a crime they did not commit.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
384.title: IPC Section 348: Wrongful confinement to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

385.text:
IPC Section 349: Force

Description: A person is said to use force to another if he causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that other, or if he causes to any substance such motion as brings that substance into contact with any part of that other's body.

Example Use Cases: Pushing someone; throwing an object at someone.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
385.title: IPC Section 349: Force

386.text:
IPC Section 350: Criminal force

Description: Whoever intentionally uses force to any person, without that person's consent, in order to commit an offence, or intending to cause injury, fear or annoyance to that person, is said to use criminal force to that other.

Example Use Cases: Slapping someone to insult them; pushing someone out of the way to steal their bag.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 352.
386.title: IPC Section 350: Criminal force

387.text:
IPC Section 351: Assault

Description: Whoever makes any gesture, or any preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture or preparation will cause any person present to apprehend that he who makes that gesture or preparation is about to use criminal force to that person, is said to commit an assault.

Example Use Cases: Raising a fist as if to punch someone; aiming a gun at someone.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 352.
387.title: IPC Section 351: Assault

388.text:
IPC Section 352: Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A minor scuffle or slap in a argument.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
388.title: IPC Section 352: Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation

389.text:
IPC Section 353: Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Pushing a government official who is performing their duty.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
389.title: IPC Section 353: Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty

390.text:
IPC Section 354: Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Eve-teasing; inappropriate touching.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than one year but which may extend to five years, and fine.
390.title: IPC Section 354: Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty

391.text:
IPC Section 354A: Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment

Description: A man committing any of the following acts: physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures; a demand or request for sexual favours; showing pornography against the will of a woman; making sexually coloured remarks.

Example Use Cases: Making unwelcome physical contact; demanding sexual favours in exchange for a promotion.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
391.title: IPC Section 354A: Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment

392.text:
IPC Section 354B: Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe

Description: Any man who assaults or uses criminal force to any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Attempting to remove a woman's clothes against her will.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and fine.
392.title: IPC Section 354B: Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe

393.text:
IPC Section 354C: Voyeurism

Description: Any man who watches, or captures the image of, a woman engaging in a private act where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Secretly filming a woman in her bedroom or bathroom.

Punishment: First conviction: imprisonment one to three years and fine. Subsequent conviction: three to seven years and fine.
393.title: IPC Section 354C: Voyeurism

394.text:
IPC Section 354D: Stalking

Description: Any man who follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact, her to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest by such woman, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Repeatedly sending unwanted messages; following a woman home.

Punishment: First conviction: imprisonment up to three years and fine. Subsequent conviction: imprisonment up to five years and fine.
394.title: IPC Section 354D: Stalking

395.text:
IPC Section 355: Assault or criminal force with intent to dishonour person, otherwise than on grave provocation

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to dishonor that person, otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Slapping someone to humiliate them in public.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
395.title: IPC Section 355: Assault or criminal force with intent to dishonour person, otherwise than on grave provocation

396.text:
IPC Section 356: Assault or criminal force in attempt to commit theft of property carried by a person

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting to commit theft on any property which that person is then wearing or carrying, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Snatching a chain from a person's neck and pushing them down.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
396.title: IPC Section 356: Assault or criminal force in attempt to commit theft of property carried by a person

397.text:
IPC Section 357: Assault or criminal force in attempt wrongfully to confine a person

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting wrongfully to confine that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using force to try and drag someone into a car to kidnap them.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
397.title: IPC Section 357: Assault or criminal force in attempt wrongfully to confine a person

398.text:
IPC Section 358: Assault or criminal force on grave provocation

Description: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A sudden physical reaction to a severe and immediate provocation.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one month, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.
398.title: IPC Section 358: Assault or criminal force on grave provocation

399.text:
IPC Section 359: Kidnapping

Description: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.

Example Use Cases: Defines the two types of kidnapping.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
399.title: IPC Section 359: Kidnapping

400.text:
IPC Section 360: Kidnapping from India

Description: Whoever conveys any person beyond the limits of India without the consent of that person, or of some person legally authorized to consent on behalf of that person, is said to kidnap that person from India.

Example Use Cases: Taking someone to another country against their will.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 363.
400.title: IPC Section 360: Kidnapping from India

401.text:
IPC Section 361: Kidnapping from lawful guardianship

Description: Whoever takes or entices any minor under sixteen years of age if a male, or under eighteen years of age if a female, or any person of unsound mind, out of the keeping of the lawful guardian of such minor or person of unsound mind, without the consent of such guardian, is said to kidnap such minor or person from lawful guardianship.

Example Use Cases: Taking a child away from their parents without permission.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 363.
401.title: IPC Section 361: Kidnapping from lawful guardianship

402.text:
IPC Section 362: Abduction

Description: Whoever by force compels, or by any deceitful means induces, any person to go from any place, is said to abduct that person.

Example Use Cases: Forcibly taking someone away; tricking someone into coming with you.

Punishment: Punishment as per the purpose of abduction (e.g., Sections 364, 365, 366).
402.title: IPC Section 362: Abduction

403.text:
IPC Section 363: Punishment for kidnapping

Description: Whoever kidnaps any person from India or from lawful guardianship, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: The basic offence of kidnapping.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
403.title: IPC Section 363: Punishment for kidnapping

404.text:
IPC Section 363A: Kidnapping or maiming a minor for purposes of begging

Description: Whoever kidnaps any minor for the purpose of begging, or whoever maims a minor to be used for begging, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Stealing a child to force them to beg; crippling a child to make them a more effective beggar.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine. For maiming: imprisonment not less than ten years and fine.
404.title: IPC Section 363A: Kidnapping or maiming a minor for purposes of begging

405.text:
IPC Section 364: Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be murdered or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being murdered, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Abducting someone with the intention of killing them.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
405.title: IPC Section 364: Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder

406.text:
IPC Section 364A: Kidnapping for ransom, etc.

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person and threatens to cause death or hurt to such person, or by his conduct gives rise to a reasonable apprehension that such person may be put to death or hurt, in order to compel the Government or any other person to pay a ransom, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Holding someone hostage and demanding money for their release.

Punishment: Death, or imprisonment for life, and fine.
406.title: IPC Section 364A: Kidnapping for ransom, etc.

407.text:
IPC Section 365: Kidnapping or abducting with intent secretly and wrongfully to confine person

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person with the intent to cause that person to be secretly and wrongfully confined, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Kidnapping someone to hold them captive in an unknown location.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
407.title: IPC Section 365: Kidnapping or abducting with intent secretly and wrongfully to confine person

408.text:
IPC Section 366: Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc.

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled, or knowing it to be likely that she will be compelled, to marry any person against her will, or in order that she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Abducting a woman to force her into marriage.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
408.title: IPC Section 366: Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc.

409.text:
IPC Section 366A: Procuration of minor girl

Description: Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any minor girl under the age of eighteen years to go from any place or to do any act with the intent that such girl may be, or knowing that it is likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Luring a young girl away from her home with the intention of selling her into prostitution.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
409.title: IPC Section 366A: Procuration of minor girl

410.text:
IPC Section 366B: Importation of girl from foreign country

Description: Whoever imports into India from any country outside India any girl under the age of twenty-one years with the intent that she may be, or knowing it to be likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Trafficking a young woman from another country for the sex trade.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
410.title: IPC Section 366B: Importation of girl from foreign country

411.text:
IPC Section 367: Kidnapping or abducting in order to subject person to grievous hurt, slavery, etc.

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be subjected to grievous hurt, or to the unnatural lust of any person, or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being subjected to grievous hurt, or slavery, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Abducting someone to torture them or to force them into slave labour.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
411.title: IPC Section 367: Kidnapping or abducting in order to subject person to grievous hurt, slavery, etc.

412.text:
IPC Section 368: Wrongfully concealing or keeping in confinement, kidnapped or abducted person

Description: Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines such person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Hiding a person who has been kidnapped by someone else.

Punishment: Punishment for the same term as for kidnapping or abducting that person.
412.title: IPC Section 368: Wrongfully concealing or keeping in confinement, kidnapped or abducted person

413.text:
IPC Section 369: Kidnapping or abducting child under ten years with intent to steal from its person

Description: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking any property from the person of such child, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Stealing a young child to rob them of jewellery they are wearing.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
413.title: IPC Section 369: Kidnapping or abducting child under ten years with intent to steal from its person

414.text:
IPC Section 370: Trafficking of person

Description: Whoever, for the purpose of exploitation, recruits, transports, harbours, transfers, or receives a person, by using threats, force, or other forms of coercion, abduction, fraud, deception, abuse of power, or by giving payments or benefits, commits the offence of trafficking.

Example Use Cases: Recruiting people with false promises of jobs and forcing them into prostitution or bonded labour.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than seven years but which may extend to ten years, and fine. For more than one person, or a minor: imprisonment not less than ten years which may extend to life, and fine.
414.title: IPC Section 370: Trafficking of person

415.text:
IPC Section 370A: Exploitation of a trafficked person

Description: Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that a person has been trafficked, engages such person for exploitation, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using a trafficked person as forced labour or in the sex trade.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to seven years, and fine.
415.title: IPC Section 370A: Exploitation of a trafficked person

416.text:
IPC Section 371: Habitual dealing in slaves

Description: Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or deals in slaves, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Operating a business that trades in people as slaves.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
416.title: IPC Section 371: Habitual dealing in slaves

417.text:
IPC Section 372: Selling minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.

Description: Whoever sells, lets to hire, or otherwise disposes of any person under the age of eighteen years with the intent that such person shall be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling one's own child to a brothel.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
417.title: IPC Section 372: Selling minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.

418.text:
IPC Section 373: Buying minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.

Description: Whoever buys, hires or otherwise obtains possession of any person under the age of eighteen years with the intent that such person shall be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Purchasing a minor to work in a brothel.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
418.title: IPC Section 373: Buying minor for purposes of prostitution, etc.

419.text:
IPC Section 374: Unlawful compulsory labour

Description: Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will of that person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Forcing someone to work without pay and against their will.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
419.title: IPC Section 374: Unlawful compulsory labour

420.text:
IPC Section 375: Rape

Description: A man is said to commit "rape" if he has sexual intercourse with a woman against her will, without her consent, with her consent when obtained under fear of death or hurt, with her consent when the man knows he is not her husband, or with a woman under eighteen years of age with or without her consent.

Example Use Cases: Sexual assault involving penetration without consent.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 376.
420.title: IPC Section 375: Rape

421.text:
IPC Section 376: Punishment for rape

Description: Whoever, except in the cases provided for in subsection (2), commits rape, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: The basic offence of rape.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment not less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and fine.
421.title: IPC Section 376: Punishment for rape

422.text:
IPC Section 376A: Intercourse by a man with his wife during separation

Description: Whoever has sexual intercourse with his own wife, who is living separately from him under a decree of separation or under any custom or usage, without her consent, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Marital rape during a period of judicial separation.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
422.title: IPC Section 376A: Intercourse by a man with his wife during separation

423.text:
IPC Section 376B: Sexual intercourse by public servant with woman in his custody

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, takes advantage of his official position and induces or seduces any woman in his custody to have sexual intercourse with him, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A police officer having sex with a woman in his custody.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to ten years, and fine.
423.title: IPC Section 376B: Sexual intercourse by public servant with woman in his custody

424.text:
IPC Section 376C: Sexual intercourse by superintendent of jail, remand home, etc.

Description: Whoever, being the superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home or other institution, has sexual intercourse with any inmate, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A jail warden having sex with a prisoner.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to ten years, and fine.
424.title: IPC Section 376C: Sexual intercourse by superintendent of jail, remand home, etc.

425.text:
IPC Section 376D: Sexual intercourse by any person with any woman in custody

Description: Whoever, being on the management or staff of a hospital, has sexual intercourse with any woman in that hospital, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A hospital staff member having sex with a patient.

Punishment: Imprisonment not less than five years but which may extend to ten years, and fine.
425.title: IPC Section 376D: Sexual intercourse by any person with any woman in custody

426.text:
IPC Section 376E: Punishment for repeat offenders

Description: Whoever has been previously convicted of an offence punishable under Section 376 or 376A to 376D and is subsequently convicted of an offence punishable under any of these sections, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person convicted of rape commits another rape after release.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or death.
426.title: IPC Section 376E: Punishment for repeat offenders

427.text:
IPC Section 377: Unnatural offences

Description: Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Anal intercourse, bestiality.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
427.title: IPC Section 377: Unnatural offences

428.text:
IPC Section 378: Theft

Description: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.

Example Use Cases: Taking someone's phone without their permission.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 379.
428.title: IPC Section 378: Theft

429.text:
IPC Section 379: Punishment for theft

Description: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Shoplifting; pickpocketing.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
429.title: IPC Section 379: Punishment for theft

430.text:
IPC Section 380: Theft in dwelling house, etc.

Description: Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Breaking into a house and stealing valuables.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
430.title: IPC Section 380: Theft in dwelling house, etc.

431.text:
IPC Section 381: Theft by clerk or servant of property in possession of master

Description: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A domestic servant stealing jewelry from the employer's house.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
431.title: IPC Section 381: Theft by clerk or servant of property in possession of master

432.text:
IPC Section 382: Theft after preparation made for causing death, hurt or restraint in order to the committing of the theft

Description: Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, hurt or restraint to any person in order to the committing of such theft, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Carrying a weapon while committing theft to use if confronted.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
432.title: IPC Section 382: Theft after preparation made for causing death, hurt or restraint in order to the committing of the theft

433.text:
IPC Section 383: Extortion

Description: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property or valuable security, commits extortion.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to harm someone unless they give you money.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 384.
433.title: IPC Section 383: Extortion

434.text:
IPC Section 384: Punishment for extortion

Description: Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Demanding money through threats.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
434.title: IPC Section 384: Punishment for extortion

435.text:
IPC Section 385: Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion

Description: Whoever, in order to commit extortion, puts any person in fear of any injury, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening someone as a preliminary to making a demand for money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
435.title: IPC Section 385: Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion

436.text:
IPC Section 386: Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt

Description: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to kill someone unless they pay a ransom.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
436.title: IPC Section 386: Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt

437.text:
IPC Section 387: Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt

Description: Whoever, in order to commit extortion, puts any person in fear of death or grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Making a threat of serious harm to prepare for extortion.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
437.title: IPC Section 387: Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt

438.text:
IPC Section 388: Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death, etc.

Description: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of an accusation against that person or any other of having committed an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for ten years, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to falsely accuse someone of a serious crime unless they pay money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
438.title: IPC Section 388: Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death, etc.

439.text:
IPC Section 389: Putting person in fear of accusation of offence, in order to commit extortion

Description: Whoever, in order to commit extortion, puts any person in fear of an accusation against that person or any other of having committed an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for ten years, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to frame someone for a serious crime to extort money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
439.title: IPC Section 389: Putting person in fear of accusation of offence, in order to commit extortion

440.text:
IPC Section 390: Robbery

Description: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. Theft is robbery if it is committed in order to or while committing theft, the offender causes or attempts to cause to any person death, hurt or wrongful restraint. Extortion is robbery if the offender induces the person put in fear to deliver up the property at the time and place of the extortion.

Example Use Cases: Snatching a purse and pushing the owner to the ground.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 392.
440.title: IPC Section 390: Robbery

441.text:
IPC Section 391: Dacoity

Description: When five or more persons conjointly commit or attempt to commit a robbery, they are said to commit dacoity.

Example Use Cases: A gang of five people committing a bank robbery.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 395.
441.title: IPC Section 391: Dacoity

442.text:
IPC Section 392: Punishment for robbery

Description: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; if the robbery is committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, the imprisonment may be extended to fourteen years.

Example Use Cases: Mugging someone on the street.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine. On highway between sunset and sunrise: up to fourteen years.
442.title: IPC Section 392: Punishment for robbery

443.text:
IPC Section 393: Attempt to commit robbery

Description: Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Attempting to mug someone but being fought off.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
443.title: IPC Section 393: Attempt to commit robbery

444.text:
IPC Section 394: Voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery

Description: If any person, in committing or in attempting to commit robbery, voluntarily causes hurt, such person shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing injury to a victim during a robbery.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
444.title: IPC Section 394: Voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery

445.text:
IPC Section 395: Punishment for dacoity

Description: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: A gang robbery involving five or more persons.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
445.title: IPC Section 395: Punishment for dacoity

446.text:
IPC Section 396: Dacoity with murder

Description: If any one of five or more persons who are conjointly committing dacoity commits murder in so committing dacoity, every one of those persons shall be punished with death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for ten years.

Example Use Cases: A member of a dacoity gang kills a victim during the robbery.

Punishment: Death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years.
446.title: IPC Section 396: Dacoity with murder

447.text:
IPC Section 397: Robbery or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt

Description: If, at the time of committing robbery or dacoity, the offender uses any deadly weapon, or causes grievous hurt to any person, or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt, he shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using a knife or gun during a robbery.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than seven years.
447.title: IPC Section 397: Robbery or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt

448.text:
IPC Section 398: Attempt to commit robbery or dacoity when armed with deadly weapon

Description: If, at the time of attempting to commit robbery or dacoity, the offender is armed with any deadly weapon, the imprisonment shall not be less than seven years.

Example Use Cases: Being caught with a weapon while planning a robbery.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than seven years.
448.title: IPC Section 398: Attempt to commit robbery or dacoity when armed with deadly weapon

449.text:
IPC Section 399: Making preparation to commit dacoity

Description: Whoever makes any preparation for committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Gathering weapons and planning a route for a gang robbery.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
449.title: IPC Section 399: Making preparation to commit dacoity

450.text:
IPC Section 400: Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits

Description: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall belong to a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being a member of a gang known for repeated robberies.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
450.title: IPC Section 400: Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits

451.text:
IPC Section 401: Punishment for belonging to gang of thieves

Description: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall belong to any wandering or other gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing theft or robbery, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being part of a organized theft ring.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
451.title: IPC Section 401: Punishment for belonging to gang of thieves

452.text:
IPC Section 402: Assembling for purpose of committing dacoity

Description: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall be one of five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Meeting with four others to plan and execute a robbery.

Punishment: Rigorous imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
452.title: IPC Section 402: Assembling for purpose of committing dacoity

453.text:
IPC Section 403: Dishonest misappropriation of property

Description: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Finding a lost phone and keeping it instead of returning it.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
453.title: IPC Section 403: Dishonest misappropriation of property

454.text:
IPC Section 404: Dishonest misappropriation of property possessed by deceased person at the time of his death

Description: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use property, knowing that it was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of that person's death, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Stealing jewelry from a dead body.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If by clerk or servant: imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
454.title: IPC Section 404: Dishonest misappropriation of property possessed by deceased person at the time of his death

455.text:
IPC Section 405: Criminal breach of trust
