Description: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, dishonestly misappropriates or converts that property to his own use, shall be committed criminal breach of trust.

Example Use Cases: A banker misusing a client's funds; a trustee stealing from the trust.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 406.
455.title: IPC Section 405: Criminal breach of trust

456.text:
IPC Section 406: Punishment for criminal breach of trust

Description: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: An employee stealing company funds.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
456.title: IPC Section 406: Punishment for criminal breach of trust

457.text:
IPC Section 407: Criminal breach of trust by carrier, etc.

Description: Whoever, being entrusted with property as a carrier, wharfinger or warehouse-keeper, commits criminal breach of trust, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A shipping company losing or stealing goods in transit.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
457.title: IPC Section 407: Criminal breach of trust by carrier, etc.

458.text:
IPC Section 408: Criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant

Description: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of any property entrusted to him, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: An accountant embezzling company money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
458.title: IPC Section 408: Criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant

459.text:
IPC Section 409: Criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent

Description: Whoever, being a public servant, banker, merchant, or agent, commits criminal breach of trust, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A government officer misusing public funds; a bank manager stealing deposits.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
459.title: IPC Section 409: Criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent

460.text:
IPC Section 410: Stolen property

Description: Property, the possession whereof has been transferred by theft, extortion, or robbery, is called stolen property.

Example Use Cases: Defines stolen property for subsequent sections.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
460.title: IPC Section 410: Stolen property

461.text:
IPC Section 411: Dishonestly receiving stolen property

Description: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing it to be stolen property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Buying a phone knowing it was stolen.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
461.title: IPC Section 411: Dishonestly receiving stolen property

462.text:
IPC Section 412: Dishonestly receiving property stolen in the commission of a dacoity

Description: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing it to have been stolen in the commission of a dacoity, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Receiving goods taken during a gang robbery.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
462.title: IPC Section 412: Dishonestly receiving property stolen in the commission of a dacoity

463.text:
IPC Section 413: Habitually dealing in stolen property

Description: Whoever habitually receives or deals in property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Operating a business that sells stolen goods.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
463.title: IPC Section 413: Habitually dealing in stolen property

464.text:
IPC Section 414: Assisting in concealment of stolen property

Description: Whoever voluntarily assists in concealing or disposing of stolen property, knowing it to be stolen, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Helping to hide stolen goods.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
464.title: IPC Section 414: Assisting in concealment of stolen property

465.text:
IPC Section 415: Cheating

Description: Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces that person to deliver any property, or to consent to retain any property, is said to cheat.

Example Use Cases: Defines cheating for subsequent sections.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
465.title: IPC Section 415: Cheating

466.text:
IPC Section 416: Cheating by personation

Description: A person is said to cheat by personation if he cheats by pretending to be some other person, or by knowingly substituting one person for another.

Example Use Cases: Impersonating someone else to collect their money or benefits.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 419.
466.title: IPC Section 416: Cheating by personation

467.text:
IPC Section 417: Punishment for cheating

Description: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: A simple case of fraud.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
467.title: IPC Section 417: Punishment for cheating

468.text:
IPC Section 418: Cheating with knowledge that wrongful loss may ensue to person whose interest offender is bound to protect

Description: Whoever cheats with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause wrongful loss to a person whose interest he is bound to protect, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A lawyer cheating his client.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
468.title: IPC Section 418: Cheating with knowledge that wrongful loss may ensue to person whose interest offender is bound to protect

469.text:
IPC Section 419: Punishment for cheating by personation

Description: Whoever cheats by personation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Impersonating someone in an exam or to obtain a passport.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
469.title: IPC Section 419: Punishment for cheating by personation

470.text:
IPC Section 420: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property

Description: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A large-scale fraud involving delivery of property or money.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
470.title: IPC Section 420: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property

471.text:
IPC Section 421: Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent distribution among creditors

Description: Whoever dishonestly removes, conceals, or delivers to any person any property to prevent it from being taken in execution of a decree, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Hiding assets to avoid paying debts.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
471.title: IPC Section 421: Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property to prevent distribution among creditors

472.text:
IPC Section 422: Dishonestly or fraudulently preventing debt being available for creditors

Description: Whoever dishonestly prevents a debt from being made available for his creditors, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Helping a debtor hide their assets.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
472.title: IPC Section 422: Dishonestly or fraudulently preventing debt being available for creditors

473.text:
IPC Section 423: Dishonest or fraudulent execution of deed of transfer containing false statement of consideration

Description: Whoever dishonestly signs a document that contains a false statement about its value or consideration, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Forging a deed of sale with a false price.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
473.title: IPC Section 423: Dishonest or fraudulent execution of deed of transfer containing false statement of consideration

474.text:
IPC Section 424: Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property

Description: Whoever dishonestly conceals or removes any property of himself or another, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Hiding property to avoid seizure.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
474.title: IPC Section 424: Dishonest or fraudulent removal or concealment of property

475.text:
IPC Section 425: Mischief

Description: Whoever, with intent to cause wrongful loss or damage to the public or any person, causes the destruction of property, or such change that destroys its value or utility, commits mischief.

Example Use Cases: Vandalizing a car; breaking windows.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 426.
475.title: IPC Section 425: Mischief

476.text:
IPC Section 426: Punishment for mischief

Description: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Minor vandalism.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine, or both.
476.title: IPC Section 426: Punishment for mischief

477.text:
IPC Section 427: Mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees

Description: Whoever commits mischief and thereby causes loss or damage to the amount of fifty rupees or upwards, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing significant property damage.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
477.title: IPC Section 427: Mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees

478.text:
IPC Section 428: Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal

Description: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal worth ten rupees or more, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Poisoning a neighbor's dog.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
478.title: IPC Section 428: Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal

479.text:
IPC Section 429: Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal

Description: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any elephant, camel, horse, etc., or any animal worth fifty rupees or more, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Killing a valuable cow or horse.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years, or fine, or both.
479.title: IPC Section 429: Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal

480.text:
IPC Section 430: Mischief by injury to works of irrigation or by wrongfully diverting water

Description: Whoever commits mischief by injury to any irrigation work, or wrongfully diverts water, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Damaging a canal or dam; illegally diverting a water source.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years, or fine, or both.
480.title: IPC Section 430: Mischief by injury to works of irrigation or by wrongfully diverting water

481.text:
IPC Section 431: Mischief by injury to public road, bridge, river or channel

Description: Whoever commits mischief by injury to any public road, bridge, river or channel, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Damaging a public bridge.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years, or fine, or both.
481.title: IPC Section 431: Mischief by injury to public road, bridge, river or channel

482.text:
IPC Section 432: Mischief by causing inundation or obstruction to public drainage attended with damage

Description: Whoever commits mischief by causing an inundation or obstruction to any public drainage, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Blocking a public drain causing flooding.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years, or fine, or both.
482.title: IPC Section 432: Mischief by causing inundation or obstruction to public drainage attended with damage

483.text:
IPC Section 433: Mischief by destroying, moving or rendering less useful a lighthouse or sea-mark

Description: Whoever commits mischief by destroying or moving a lighthouse or other sea-mark, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Tampering with navigation aids.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
483.title: IPC Section 433: Mischief by destroying, moving or rendering less useful a lighthouse or sea-mark

484.text:
IPC Section 434: Mischief by destroying or moving, etc., a landmark fixed by public authority

Description: Whoever commits mischief by destroying or moving a landmark fixed by public authority, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Removing a boundary stone.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
484.title: IPC Section 434: Mischief by destroying or moving, etc., a landmark fixed by public authority

485.text:
IPC Section 435: Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to cause damage

Description: Whoever commits mischief by fire or explosive substance intending to cause damage, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Arson of a building or property.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
485.title: IPC Section 435: Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to cause damage

486.text:
IPC Section 436: Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc.

Description: Whoever commits mischief by fire or explosive substance intending to destroy a house, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Setting a house on fire.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
486.title: IPC Section 436: Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc.

487.text:
IPC Section 437: Mischief with intent to destroy or make unsafe a decked vessel or one of twenty tons burden

Description: Whoever commits mischief to a ship or vessel, intending to destroy it or make it unsafe, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Sabotaging a boat.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
487.title: IPC Section 437: Mischief with intent to destroy or make unsafe a decked vessel or one of twenty tons burden

488.text:
IPC Section 438: Punishment for the mischief described in section 437 committed by fire or explosive substance

Description: Whoever commits mischief described in the previous section by fire or explosive substance, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Setting a ship on fire.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
488.title: IPC Section 438: Punishment for the mischief described in section 437 committed by fire or explosive substance

489.text:
IPC Section 439: Punishment for intentionally running vessel aground or ashore with intent to commit theft, etc.

Description: Whoever intentionally runs a vessel aground or ashore, intending to commit theft or mischief, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Intentionally grounding a ship to loot it.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
489.title: IPC Section 439: Punishment for intentionally running vessel aground or ashore with intent to commit theft, etc.

490.text:
IPC Section 440: Mischief committed after preparation made for causing death or hurt

Description: Whoever commits mischief, having made preparation for causing death or hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Preparing to use force while committing vandalism.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine.
490.title: IPC Section 440: Mischief committed after preparation made for causing death or hurt

491.text:
IPC Section 441: Criminal trespass

Description: Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property, commits criminal trespass.

Example Use Cases: Entering someone's land with the intent to steal or threaten.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 447.
491.title: IPC Section 441: Criminal trespass

492.text:
IPC Section 442: House-trespass

Description: Whoever commits criminal trespass by entering into any building, tent or vessel used as a human dwelling, commits house-trespass.

Example Use Cases: Breaking into a house.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 448.
492.title: IPC Section 442: House-trespass

493.text:
IPC Section 443: Lurking house-trespass

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass having taken precautions to conceal such trespass from the owner, commits lurking house-trespass.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house at night to avoid being seen.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 453.
493.title: IPC Section 443: Lurking house-trespass

494.text:
IPC Section 444: Lurking house-trespass by night

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass after sunset and before sunrise, commits lurking house-trespass by night.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house at night.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 456.
494.title: IPC Section 444: Lurking house-trespass by night

495.text:
IPC Section 445: House-breaking

Description: A person is said to commit house-breaking who commits house-trespass if he enters through a passage not intended for entrance, or by any means that amounts to breaking.

Example Use Cases: Breaking a window to enter a house.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 453.
495.title: IPC Section 445: House-breaking

496.text:
IPC Section 446: House-breaking by night

Description: Whoever commits house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise, commits house-breaking by night.

Example Use Cases: Breaking into a house at night.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 456.
496.title: IPC Section 446: House-breaking by night

497.text:
IPC Section 447: Punishment for criminal trespass

Description: Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine up to five hundred rupees, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Trespassing on someone's property.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.
497.title: IPC Section 447: Punishment for criminal trespass

498.text:
IPC Section 448: Punishment for house-trespass

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Entering someone's house without permission.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
498.title: IPC Section 448: Punishment for house-trespass

499.text:
IPC Section 449: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass in order to commit an offence punishable with death, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Entering a house to commit murder.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
499.title: IPC Section 449: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death

500.text:
IPC Section 450: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment for life

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass in order to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment for life, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Entering a house to commit rape.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
500.title: IPC Section 450: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment for life

501.text:
IPC Section 451: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass in order to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Entering a house to commit theft.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
501.title: IPC Section 451: House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

502.text:
IPC Section 452: House-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

Description: Whoever commits house-trespass, having made preparation for causing hurt, assault, or wrongful restraint, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Entering a house armed with a weapon.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
502.title: IPC Section 452: House-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

503.text:
IPC Section 453: Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years and fine.
503.title: IPC Section 453: Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking

504.text:
IPC Section 454: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house to commit theft.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine. If the offence is theft: imprisonment up to ten years.
504.title: IPC Section 454: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

505.text:
IPC Section 455: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, having made preparation for causing hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house armed with a weapon.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
505.title: IPC Section 455: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

506.text:
IPC Section 456: Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Example Use Cases: Sneaking into a house at night.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
506.title: IPC Section 456: Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night

507.text:
IPC Section 457: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Breaking into a house at night to commit theft.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years and fine. If the offence is theft: imprisonment up to fourteen years.
507.title: IPC Section 457: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment

508.text:
IPC Section 458: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

Description: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night, having made preparation for causing hurt, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Breaking into a house at night armed with a weapon.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to fourteen years and fine.
508.title: IPC Section 458: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint

509.text:
IPC Section 459: Grievous hurt caused whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking

Description: If any person, whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, causes grievous hurt, he shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing serious injury to a homeowner during a break-in.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
509.title: IPC Section 459: Grievous hurt caused whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking

510.text:
IPC Section 460: Death or grievous hurt caused by one of several persons jointly concerned in house-breaking by night

Description: If, when several persons are jointly committing house-breaking by night, one of them causes grievous hurt or death, all are guilty of this offence.

Example Use Cases: A member of a gang breaking into a house at night kills the owner.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
510.title: IPC Section 460: Death or grievous hurt caused by one of several persons jointly concerned in house-breaking by night

511.text:
IPC Section 461: Dishonestly breaking open receptacle containing property

Description: Whoever dishonestly breaks open any container containing property, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Breaking open a locked box or cupboard to steal what is inside.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
511.title: IPC Section 461: Dishonestly breaking open receptacle containing property

512.text:
IPC Section 462: Punishment for same offence when committed by person entrusted with custody

Description: If the offender is entrusted with the custody of the container he breaks open, the punishment is higher.

Example Use Cases: A bank employee breaking open a safe they are supposed to guard.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
512.title: IPC Section 462: Punishment for same offence when committed by person entrusted with custody

513.text:
IPC Section 463: Forgery

Description: Whoever makes any false document or electronic record with intent to cause damage or injury, is said to commit forgery.

Example Use Cases: Creating a fake contract or will.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 465.
513.title: IPC Section 463: Forgery

514.text:
IPC Section 464: Making a false document

Description: A person is said to make a false document if he makes a document that purports to be made by someone else, or by a fictitious person, or if he alters a document without authority.

Example Use Cases: Signing someone else's name on a check.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 465.
514.title: IPC Section 464: Making a false document

515.text:
IPC Section 465: Punishment for forgery

Description: Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Forging a signature on a document.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
515.title: IPC Section 465: Punishment for forgery

516.text:
IPC Section 466: Forgery of record of Court or of public register, etc.

Description: Whoever forges a document which is a record of a Court or a public register, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Forging a court judgment or a land record.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
516.title: IPC Section 466: Forgery of record of Court or of public register, etc.

517.text:
IPC Section 467: Forgery of valuable security, will, etc.

Description: Whoever forges a valuable security, a will, or an authority to adopt a son, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Forging a promissory note or a will.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
517.title: IPC Section 467: Forgery of valuable security, will, etc.

518.text:
IPC Section 468: Forgery for purpose of cheating

Description: Whoever commits forgery, intending that the document forged shall be used for the purpose of cheating, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating a fake degree certificate to get a job.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
518.title: IPC Section 468: Forgery for purpose of cheating

519.text:
IPC Section 469: Forgery for purpose of harming reputation

Description: Whoever commits forgery, intending that the document forged shall harm the reputation of any person, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating a fake letter to damage someone's character.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
519.title: IPC Section 469: Forgery for purpose of harming reputation

520.text:
IPC Section 470: Forged document or electronic record

Description: A forged document or electronic record is one that is forged within the meaning of this Code.

Example Use Cases: Defines forged document for subsequent sections.

Punishment: Not a penal section; it is a definition clause.
520.title: IPC Section 470: Forged document or electronic record

521.text:
IPC Section 471: Using as genuine a forged document or electronic record

Description: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document which he knows to be forged, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using a forged passport to travel.

Punishment: Punished as for forgery of such document.
521.title: IPC Section 471: Using as genuine a forged document or electronic record

522.text:
IPC Section 472: Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery

Description: Whoever makes or possesses any die or instrument for the purpose of forging, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Making a fake rubber stamp of a government office.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
522.title: IPC Section 472: Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery

523.text:
IPC Section 473: Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery

Description: Whoever makes or possesses any such die or instrument knowing it to be counterfeit, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Possessing equipment to forge documents.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
523.title: IPC Section 473: Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery

524.text:
IPC Section 474: Having possession of document described in section 466 or 467, knowing it to be forged

Description: Whoever has in his possession a forged document described in Section 466 or 467, knowing it to be forged, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being in possession of a forged will or valuable security.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
524.title: IPC Section 474: Having possession of document described in section 466 or 467, knowing it to be forged

525.text:
IPC Section 475: Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents

Description: Whoever counterfeits any device or mark used for authenticating documents, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Copying a hologram or official seal used on documents.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to seven years, and fine.
525.title: IPC Section 475: Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents

526.text:
IPC Section 476: Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents

Description: Whoever counterfeits any such device or mark with intent to commit forgery, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating a fake official stamp.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
526.title: IPC Section 476: Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents

527.text:
IPC Section 477: Fraudulent cancellation, destruction, etc., of will, etc.

Description: Whoever fraudulently cancels, destroys, or defaces a will or other valuable security, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Destroying a will to prevent someone from inheriting.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to seven years, and fine.
527.title: IPC Section 477: Fraudulent cancellation, destruction, etc., of will, etc.

528.text:
IPC Section 477A: Falsification of accounts

Description: Whoever, being a clerk or officer, falsifies any account, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: An accountant cooking the books to hide embezzlement.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
528.title: IPC Section 477A: Falsification of accounts

541.text:
IPC Section 489A: Counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes

Description: Whoever counterfeits any currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Printing fake Indian rupee notes.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
541.title: IPC Section 489A: Counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes

542.text:
IPC Section 489B: Using as genuine, forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes

Description: Whoever sells to, or buys from, any person, or uses as genuine, any forged or counterfeit currency-note, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using counterfeit money to make a purchase.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
542.title: IPC Section 489B: Using as genuine, forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes

543.text:
IPC Section 489C: Possession of forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes

Description: Whoever has in his possession any forged or counterfeit currency-note, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Being in possession of fake currency.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years, or fine, or both.
543.title: IPC Section 489C: Possession of forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes

544.text:
IPC Section 489D: Making or possessing instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes

Description: Whoever makes or possesses any instrument or material for the purpose of counterfeiting currency, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Having printing plates and paper to make fake notes.

Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, and fine.
544.title: IPC Section 489D: Making or possessing instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes

545.text:
IPC Section 489E: Making or using documents resembling currency-notes or bank-notes

Description: Whoever makes or uses any document resembling a currency-note, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Creating movie prop money that looks too real.

Punishment: Fine up to one hundred rupees.
545.title: IPC Section 489E: Making or using documents resembling currency-notes or bank-notes

IPC Section 490: [Repealed]

547.text:
IPC Section 491: Breach of contract to attend on and supply wants of helpless person

Description: Whoever, being bound by a contract to attend on a helpless person, fails to do so, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A nurse under contract abandons a bedridden patient.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three months, or fine up to two hundred rupees, or both.
547.title: IPC Section 491: Breach of contract to attend on and supply wants of helpless person

IPC Section 492: [Repealed]

Description: [Repealed]

Example Use Cases: [Repealed]

549.text:
IPC Section 493: Cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage

Description: Whoever, by deceit, induces a woman to have sexual intercourse with him by pretending to be married to her, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A man fake marries a woman to have sex with her.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
549.title: IPC Section 493: Cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage

550.text:
IPC Section 494: Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife

Description: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries again, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A person commits bigamy by marrying a second time without divorcing their first spouse.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
550.title: IPC Section 494: Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife

551.text:
IPC Section 495: Same offence with concealment of former marriage from person with whom subsequent marriage is contracted

Description: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section and conceals the former marriage from the new spouse, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Committing bigamy and hiding the existence of the first wife/husband.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
551.title: IPC Section 495: Same offence with concealment of former marriage from person with whom subsequent marriage is contracted

552.text:
IPC Section 496: Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage

Description: Whoever, dishonestly or with a fraudulent intention, goes through a marriage ceremony knowing that it is not a legal marriage, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Performing a fake marriage ceremony to deceive someone.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
552.title: IPC Section 496: Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage

553.text:
IPC Section 497: Adultery

Description: Whoever has sexual intercourse with a person who is and whom he knows to be the wife of another man, without the consent of that man, commits adultery.

Example Use Cases: A man has an affair with a married woman.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to five years, or fine, or both. (Note: Struck down by the Supreme Court in 2018)
553.title: IPC Section 497: Adultery

554.text:
IPC Section 498: Enticing or taking away or detaining with criminal intent a married woman

Description: Whoever takes or entices away a married woman with the intent that she may have illicit intercourse, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Running away with a married woman to have an affair.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
554.title: IPC Section 498: Enticing or taking away or detaining with criminal intent a married woman

555.text:
IPC Section 498A: Cruelty by husband or relatives of husband

Description: Whoever, being the husband or a relative of the husband, subjects a woman to cruelty, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Harassing a wife for dowry; mental or physical abuse by in-laws.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years and fine.
555.title: IPC Section 498A: Cruelty by husband or relatives of husband

556.text:
IPC Section 499: Defamation

Description: Whoever, by words, signs, or visible representations, makes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm their reputation, is said to defame that person.

Example Use Cases: Spreading false rumors about someone's character.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 500.
556.title: IPC Section 499: Defamation

557.text:
IPC Section 500: Punishment for defamation

Description: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Example Use Cases: Libel or slander that damages a person's reputation.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
557.title: IPC Section 500: Punishment for defamation

558.text:
IPC Section 501: Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory

Description: Whoever prints or engraves any defamatory matter, knowing it to be defamatory, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Publishing a defamatory article in a newspaper.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
558.title: IPC Section 501: Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory

559.text:
IPC Section 502: Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter

Description: Whoever sells or offers for sale any printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter, knowing it to be defamatory, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Selling a book containing libelous content.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
559.title: IPC Section 502: Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter

560.text:
IPC Section 503: Criminal intimidation

Description: Whoever threatens another with injury to their person, reputation, or property, with intent to cause alarm or to make them do something, commits criminal intimidation.

Example Use Cases: Threatening to harm someone if they don't comply with a demand.

Punishment: Punishment as per Section 506.
560.title: IPC Section 503: Criminal intimidation

561.text:
IPC Section 504: Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace

Description: Whoever intentionally insults another, thereby giving provocation, intending or knowing it is likely to cause a breach of the peace, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Using abusive language in public that leads to a fight.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both.
561.title: IPC Section 504: Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace

562.text:
IPC Section 505: Statements conducing to public mischief

Description: Whoever makes, publishes, or circulates any statement or report with intent to cause fear or alarm to the public, or to incite any class to commit an offence, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Spreading a false rumor that causes panic in a community.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to three years, or fine, or both.
562.title: IPC Section 505: Statements conducing to public mischief

563.text:
IPC Section 506: Punishment for criminal intimidation

Description: Whoever commits criminal intimidation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. If the threat is to cause death or grievous hurt, the punishment is higher.

Example Use Cases: Making a threat to cause serious harm.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, or fine, or both. If threat of death/grievous hurt: imprisonment up to seven years.
563.title: IPC Section 506: Punishment for criminal intimidation

564.text:
IPC Section 507: Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication

Description: Whoever commits criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Sending threatening letters or emails without a signature.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to two years, in addition to the punishment under Section 506.
564.title: IPC Section 507: Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication

565.text:
IPC Section 508: Act caused by inducing person to believe that he will be rendered an object of the Divine displeasure

Description: Whoever causes any person to do anything by making them believe they will become an object of Divine displeasure if they do not do it, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: A fake godman threatening a person with curses.

Punishment: Imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
565.title: IPC Section 508: Act caused by inducing person to believe that he will be rendered an object of the Divine displeasure

566.text:
IPC Section 509: Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman

Description: Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of a woman, utters any word, makes any sound or gesture, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Eve-teasing; making lewd comments.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
566.title: IPC Section 509: Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman

567.text:
IPC Section 510: Misconduct in public by a drunken person

Description: Whoever, in a state of intoxication, appears in a public place and conducts himself in a disorderly manner, shall be punished.

Example Use Cases: Causing a public disturbance while drunk.

Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to twenty-four hours, or fine up to ten rupees, or both.
567.title: IPC Section 510: Misconduct in public by a drunken person

568.text:
IPC Section 511: Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment

Description: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Code with imprisonment for life or imprisonment, or to cause such an offence to be committed, shall be punished with imprisonment of any description for a term which may extend to one-half of the imprisonment for life or one-half of the longest term of imprisonment provided for that offence, and with fine.

Example Use Cases: A person is caught while trying to break into a house with the intention to commit theft (attempt to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment).

Punishment: Imprisonment for up to one-half of the maximum term provided for the attempted offence, and also liable to fine.
568.title: IPC Section 511: Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment

569.text:
# Indian Penal Code (IPC) Overview

The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal code of India that defines crimes and provides punishments for acts ranging from theft to murder. It was enacted in 1860 and has been the foundation of criminal law in India. ## Key Sections and Punishments

### Property Crimes
- **Section 378 (Theft)**: Taking moveable property from another's possession dishonestly. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years or fine or both. - **Section 379 (Punishment for theft)**: General punishment provision for theft. - **Section 380 (Theft in dwelling house)**: Enhanced punishment for theft in dwelling. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years. ### Violent Crimes  
- **Section 302 (Murder)**: Causing death with intention or knowledge likely to cause death
569.title: Ipc Overview - Part 1

570.text:
with intention or knowledge likely to cause death. Punishment: Death or life imprisonment and fine. - **Section 304 (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder)**: Punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years and fine. - **Section 323 (Voluntarily causing hurt)**: Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year or fine up to Rs. 1000 or both. - **Section 325 (Voluntarily causing grievous hurt)**: Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine. ### Financial Crimes
- **Section 420 (Cheating)**: Dishonestly inducing someone to deliver property. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine. - **Section 415 (Cheating)**: Definition of cheating by deception. - **Section 463 (Forgery)**: Making false document with intent to cause damage
570.title: Ipc Overview - Part 2

571.text:
Making false document with intent to cause damage. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both. ### Public Order
- **Section 141 (Unlawful assembly)**: Assembly of 5+ persons with common illegal object. - **Section 147 (Rioting)**: Using force or violence by unlawful assembly. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both. - **Section 153A (Promoting enmity)**: Promoting enmity between groups. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years or fine or both. ### Women and Children
- **Section 354 (Assault on woman)**: Assaulting woman to outrage modesty. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both. - **Section 376 (Rape)**: Sexual intercourse without consent. Punishment: Imprisonment 7 years to life imprisonment. ## Important Legal Principles

1
571.title: Ipc Overview - Part 3

572.text:
ife imprisonment. ## Important Legal Principles

1. **Presumption of Innocence**: Accused is innocent until proven guilty
2. **Burden of Proof**: On the prosecution to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt  
3. **Right to Legal Representation**: Every accused has right to lawyer
4. **Right Against Self-Incrimination**: Cannot be forced to give evidence against oneself

## Common Defenses
- Self-defense (Section 96-106)
- Insanity (Section 84)  
- Intoxication (Section 85-86)
- Duress/coercion
- Mistake of fact (Section 76-79)
572.title: Ipc Overview - Part 4

573.text:
# Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) Overview

The Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), 1973 governs the procedure for administration of substantive criminal law in India. It provides the framework for investigation, trial, and punishment of offenses
573.title: Crpc Overview - Part 1

574.text:
r investigation, trial, and punishment of offenses. ## Key Provisions

### Investigation and Arrest
- **Section 154**: Registration of FIR (First Information Report)
- **Section 156**: Police power to investigate cognizable offenses
- **Section 41**: When police may arrest without warrant
- **Section 50**: Person arrested to be informed of grounds
- **Section 57**: Person arrested cannot be detained beyond 24 hours without magistrate's order

### Bail Provisions
- **Section 436**: Bail for non-bailable offenses when offense punishable with death/life imprisonment
- **Section 437**: Bail for non-bailable offenses (general)
- **Section 438**: Anticipatory bail
- **Section 439**: Special powers of High Court or Court of Session regarding bail

### Trial Procedures
- **Section 207**: Supply of copies of police report and documents to accused
- **Section 225**: Trial of warrant cases by magistrate
- **Section 238**: Procedure in trial of summons cases
- **Section 313**: Power to examine accused

### Appeal and Revision
- **Section 372**: No appeal from acquittal except by State Government
- **Section 374**: Appeal from conviction
- **Section 397**: Calling for records to exercise powers of revision

## Types of Cases
1
574.title: Crpc Overview - Part 2

575.text:
o exercise powers of revision

## Types of Cases
1. **Cognizable**: Police can arrest without warrant (murder, theft, rape)
2. **Non-cognizable**: Police cannot arrest without warrant (assault, defamation)
3. **Bailable**: Entitled to bail as of right
4. **Non-bailable**: Bail at discretion of court

## Court Hierarchy
1. **Magistrate Courts**: First class and second class magistrates
2. **Sessions Courts**: Try serious offenses, death penalty cases
3. **High Courts**: Appellate jurisdiction, constitutional matters
4. **Supreme Court**: Final appellate court

## Important Time Limits
- Police custody: Maximum 15 days (in parts)
- Judicial custody: Until trial completion or bail
- Charge sheet filing: 60/90 days from arrest
- Trial completion: Preferably within 2 years
575.title: Crpc Overview - Part 3

576.text:
# How to File FIR (First Information Report)

An FIR is the first step in the criminal justice process when a cognizable offense is committed. Here's a comprehensive guide on filing an FIR. ## What is an FIR. FIR stands for First Information Report under Section 154 of CrPC. It is a written document prepared by police when they receive information about a cognizable offense. ## When to File FIR
- When a cognizable offense has been committed
- Theft, robbery, murder, rape, kidnapping, cheating, assault
- Dowry harassment, domestic violence
- Cybercrime, online fraud
- Any offense where police can arrest without warrant

## Where to File FIR
1. **Police Station**: Nearest police station to where offense occurred
2. **Online**: Many states allow online FIR for certain offenses
3
576.title: How To File Fir - Part 1

577.text:
any states allow online FIR for certain offenses
3. **By Phone**: Some urgent cases can be reported by phone first
4
577.title: How To File Fir - Part 2

578.text:
Some urgent cases can be reported by phone first
4. **Written Application**: Can submit written complaint to police

## How to File FIR

### Step 1: Visit Police Station
- Go to the police station in whose jurisdiction the offense occurred
- If unsure of jurisdiction, file at nearest police station
- Police will transfer to correct jurisdiction if needed

### Step 2: Provide Information
- **Personal Details**: Your name, address, contact number
- **Incident Details**: Date, time, place of occurrence
- **Nature of Offense**: What crime was committed
- **Description**: Detailed account of what happened
- **Suspects**: Names, descriptions if known
- **Witnesses**: Names and contacts of witnesses
- **Evidence**: Any physical evidence or documents

### Step 3: FIR Registration
- Police officer will write down your statement
- FIR will be read back to you for verification
- You will sign the FIR after confirming accuracy
- You will receive a copy of FIR with unique number

## Essential Information for FIR
1
578.title: How To File Fir - Part 3

579.text:
unique number

## Essential Information for FIR
1. **Complainant Details**
   - Full name and address
   - Relationship to victim (if different)
   - Contact information

2. **Incident Details**
   - Exact date and time
   - Location with complete address
   - Sequence of events

3. **Offense Details**
   - Type of crime committed
   - Property stolen/damaged (if any)
   - Injuries sustained (if any)

4. **Accused Details**
   - Names if known
   - Physical description
   - Any identifying features

## Important Rights
1. **Right to File FIR**: Police cannot refuse to register FIR for cognizable offense
2. **Right to Copy**: You are entitled to free copy of FIR
3
579.title: How To File Fir - Part 4

580.text:
to Copy**: You are entitled to free copy of FIR
3. **Right to Complain**: If police refuse, you can approach:
   - Superintendent of Police
   - Magistrate under Section 156(3)
   - High Court under Article 226

## What Happens After FIR
1. **Investigation**: Police start investigation
2. **Evidence Collection**: Crime scene examination, witness statements
3. **Arrest**: If suspects identified and offense serious
4. **Charge Sheet**: Filed in court within 60/90 days
5. **Trial**: Case proceeds in appropriate court

## Documents to Carry
- Identity proof (Aadhar, voter ID, passport)
- Address proof
- Medical certificates (in case of injury)
- Any relevant documents/evidence
- Photographs of injuries/damage

## Common Mistakes to Avoid
1. Don't sign blank papers
2
580.title: How To File Fir - Part 5

581.text:
mon Mistakes to Avoid
1. Don't sign blank papers
2. Don't provide false information
3. Don't omit important details
4. Don't accept money to not file FIR
5. Don't delay filing (file immediately)

## Special Cases
- **Sexual Offenses**: Female police officer should record statement
- **Online Crimes**: Can file in jurisdiction where you reside
- **Multiple Locations**: File where main offense occurred
- **Economic Offenses**: May require documents, bank statements

## Zero FIR
If offense occurs outside police station jurisdiction, they must:
1. Register Zero FIR immediately
2. Transfer to correct police station
3. Investigation starts from correct police station
581.title: How To File Fir - Part 6

582.text:
# Bail Procedure in India

Bail is the conditional release of an accused person from custody while awaiting trial. Understanding bail procedures is crucial for anyone involved in the criminal justice system. ## Types of Bail

### 1. Regular Bail (Section 437)
- Applied for after arrest and when in custody
- Available for bailable and non-bailable offenses
- Court has discretion for non-bailable offenses

### 2. Anticipatory Bail (Section 438)
- Applied for before arrest when anticipating arrest
- Only available from Sessions Court and High Court
- Prevents arrest if conditions are met

### 3
582.title: Bail Procedure - Part 1

583.text:
urt
- Prevents arrest if conditions are met

### 3. Interim Bail
- Temporary bail for short period
- Usually granted when regular bail application is pending
- Bridges gap between arrest and final bail order

## Bailable vs Non-Bailable Offenses

### Bailable Offenses
- **Right to Bail**: Accused has right to bail
- **Police Grant**: Police can grant bail at station
- **Examples**: Simple assault, theft under Rs
583.title: Bail Procedure - Part 2

584.text:
ion
- **Examples**: Simple assault, theft under Rs. 50,000, defamation
- **Procedure**: Submit bail bond with sureties

### Non-Bailable Offenses  
- **Court's Discretion**: No automatic right to bail
- **Court Only**: Only court can grant bail
- **Examples**: Murder, rape, kidnapping, dowry death, terrorism
- **Strict Conditions**: Court considers various factors

## Bail Application Procedure

### Step 1: File Application
- Submit bail application in appropriate court
- Include grounds for bail
- Attach relevant documents and affidavits

### Step 2: Court Hearing
- Prosecution may oppose bail
- Court hears arguments from both sides
- Judge considers factors for granting bail

### Step 3: Bail Order
- If granted, court specifies conditions
- Accused must execute bail bond
- Sureties must provide guarantee

### Step 4: Release
- Complete paperwork with jail authorities
- Pay any fees or fulfill conditions
- Accused released from custody

## Factors Court Considers

### For Granting Bail
1
584.title: Bail Procedure - Part 3

585.text:
# Factors Court Considers

### For Granting Bail
1. **Nature of Offense**: Seriousness of crime
2. **Evidence**: Strength of prosecution case
3. **Flight Risk**: Likelihood of absconding
4. **Tampering**: Risk of influencing witnesses/evidence
5. **Previous Record**: Past criminal history
6. **Health**: Medical condition of accused
7. **Family Ties**: Local connections, employment

### Against Granting Bail
1. **Serious Nature**: Heinous crimes like murder, rape
2. **Strong Evidence**: Prima facie case established
3. **Repeat Offender**: Previous criminal record
4. **Influence**: Position to tamper with evidence
5. **Flight Risk**: No local ties, foreign passport

## Documents Required
1. **Bail Application**: Proper legal format
2. **Affidavit**: Sworn statement of facts
3
585.title: Bail Procedure - Part 4

586.text:
ormat
2. **Affidavit**: Sworn statement of facts
3. **Surety Documents**: ID and property proof of sureties
4. **Property Documents**: If property offered as security
5. **Character Certificate**: From local authorities
6. **Employment Proof**: Job, business documents

## Bail Conditions

### Standard Conditions
1. **Attendance**: Appear in court on all dates
2. **Surrender Passport**: If foreign travel involved
3. **Local Limits**: Not leave jurisdiction without permission
4. **Reporting**: Periodic police station reporting
5. **No Contact**: Avoid contact with witnesses/victims

### Special Conditions
1. **Monetary**: Deposit certain amount with court
2. **Medical**: Regular medical check-ups
3. **Residence**: Reside at specified address
4. **Employment**: Continue specific job/business
5
586.title: Bail Procedure - Part 5

587.text:
. **Employment**: Continue specific job/business
5. **Counseling**: Attend rehabilitation programs

## Cancellation of Bail
Bail can be cancelled if:
1. **Condition Violation**: Not following bail conditions
2. **New Offense**: Committing another crime
3. **Tampering**: Influencing witnesses or evidence
4. **Absconding**: Not appearing in court
5
587.title: Bail Procedure - Part 6

588.text:
idence
4. **Absconding**: Not appearing in court
5. **Fresh Evidence**: New evidence against accused

## Appeal Process
- **Against Rejection**: Can appeal to higher court
- **Sessions to High Court**: Within 30 days
- **Magistrate to Sessions**: Within 15 days
- **High Court**: Can approach Supreme Court
- **Stay Application**: Can seek stay on non-bailable warrant

## Special Categories

### Economic Offenses
- Stricter bail conditions
- May require financial guarantees
- Court considers economic impact

### Women Accused
- Liberal bail policy
- Considering social factors
- Special protection provisions

### Juvenile Cases
- Separate juvenile justice system
- Bail more easily granted
- Guardian involvement required

## Legal Representation
- **Right to Lawyer**: Fundamental right
- **Legal Aid**: Available for poor accused
- **Experienced Counsel**: Important for complex cases
- **Court Appearance**: Lawyer can represent in most hearings

## Time Limits
- **Application Filing**: No specific time limit
- **Hearing**: Usually within 2-3 days
- **Default Bail**: Available after 60/90 days without charge sheet
- **Appeal**: Specific time limits for appeals
588.title: Bail Procedure - Part 7

589.text:
# Court System FAQ

Frequently asked questions about the Indian court system, procedures, and rights. ## General Court Questions

### Q: What are the different types of courts in India. **A:** India has a hierarchical court system:
1. **Supreme Court**: Highest court, final appellate authority
2. **High Courts**: State level, 25 High Courts across India
3. **District Courts**: District level, civil and criminal jurisdiction
4. **Sessions Courts**: Try serious criminal cases
5. **Magistrate Courts**: First class and second class magistrates
6. **Special Courts**: Family, consumer, cyber crime, etc. ### Q: How long do criminal cases take
589.title: Court Faq - Part 1

590.text:
crime, etc. ### Q: How long do criminal cases take. **A:** Time varies widely:
- **Magistrate cases**: 6 months to 2 years
- **Sessions cases**: 1-3 years
- **High Court**: 1-5 years  
- **Supreme Court**: 2-10 years
- Fast track courts aim for disposal within 1 year

### Q: What is the difference between civil and criminal cases. **A:** 
- **Criminal Cases**: Crimes against society (murder, theft, rape), prosecuted by state
- **Civil Cases**: Disputes between individuals (property, contracts, divorce)
- **Punishment**: Criminal cases result in imprisonment/fine, civil cases in compensation

## Rights and Procedures

### Q: What are the fundamental rights of an accused. **A:**
1. **Right to Legal Representation**: Free lawyer if cannot afford
2
590.title: Court Faq - Part 2

591.text:
l Representation**: Free lawyer if cannot afford
2. **Right to Bail**: For bailable offenses, discretionary for non-bailable
3. **Right Against Self-Incrimination**: Cannot be forced to testify against self
4. **Right to Fair Trial**: Speedy, public trial
5. **Right to Appeal**: Challenge conviction in higher court

### Q: When can police arrest without warrant. **A:** For cognizable offenses:
- Murder, rape, kidnapping
- Theft, robbery, burglary
- Assault with serious injury
- Dowry-related crimes
- Economic offenses above certain limits

### Q: What happens if I can't afford a lawyer
591.title: Court Faq - Part 3

592.text:
ts

### Q: What happens if I can't afford a lawyer. **A:** 
- **Legal Aid**: State provides free lawyer under Legal Services Authority Act
- **Public Defender**: Court appointed lawyer
- **NGO Help**: Various organizations provide free legal assistance
- **Law Student Clinics**: Some law colleges offer free services

## Court Procedures

### Q: How to appear in court. **A:**
1. **Dress Code**: Formal, conservative clothing
2. **Timing**: Arrive early, courts start around 10:30 AM
3. **Documents**: Carry all relevant papers, ID proof
4. **Behavior**: Stand when judge enters/leaves, address as "Your Honor"
5. **Mobile Phones**: Usually not allowed inside courtroom

### Q: What documents are needed for court
592.title: Court Faq - Part 4

593.text:
rtroom

### Q: What documents are needed for court. **A:**
- **Identity Proof**: Aadhar, voter ID, passport
- **Case Papers**: FIR copy, charge sheet, bail order
- **Evidence**: Photos, medical reports, witnesses
- **Legal Documents**: Power of attorney if lawyer representing
- **Previous Orders**: Any interim orders or judgments

### Q: Can I represent myself in court. **A:** Yes, you have the right to self-representation (in-person), but:
- **Complex Cases**: Strongly advised to have lawyer
- **Court Procedures**: Must follow proper legal procedures
- **Legal Knowledge**: Need to understand applicable laws
- **Preparation**: Must prepare case properly

## Specific Situations

### Q: What if police refuse to file FIR. **A:**
1. **Approach SP**: Superintendent of Police
2
593.title: Court Faq - Part 5

594.text:
:**
1. **Approach SP**: Superintendent of Police
2. **Magistrate Complaint**: File under Section 156(3) CrPC
3. **High Court**: Writ petition under Article 226
4. **Private Complaint**: Directly before magistrate for certain offenses

### Q: How to get certified copies of court orders. **A:**
1. **Court Registry**: Apply at court registry with fee
2. **Required Documents**: Copy application, court fee
3. **Time**: Usually takes 7-15 days
4. **Urgent Cases**: Can request urgent certified copies
5. **Lawyer**: Can authorize lawyer to collect

### Q: What is anticipatory bail
594.title: Court Faq - Part 6

595.text:
awyer to collect

### Q: What is anticipatory bail. **A:**
- **Pre-arrest**: Applied before arrest when anticipating arrest
- **Section 438**: CrPC provision for anticipatory bail
- **Courts**: Sessions court, High Court can grant
- **Conditions**: Must appear when called, not tamper with evidence
- **Duration**: Can be for specific period or until charge sheet filed

## Appeals and Reviews

### Q: How to appeal a court decision. **A:**
1. **Time Limit**: Usually 30-90 days from judgment
2. **Higher Court**: Appeal to next higher court
3. **Grounds**: Legal errors, factual errors, procedural violations
4. **Documents**: Copy of judgment, grounds of appeal
5. **Lawyer**: Essential for drafting appeal

### Q: What is revision petition
595.title: Court Faq - Part 7

596.text:
drafting appeal

### Q: What is revision petition. **A:**
- **Section 397 CrPC**: Power to call records and examine
- **Purpose**: Correct illegality or irregularity
- **Courts**: High Court, Sessions Court
- **No New Evidence**: Based on existing record
- **Time Limit**: Usually 90 days

### Q: Can I withdraw a criminal case. **A:**
- **Compoundable Offenses**: Some offenses can be settled (Section 320 CrPC)
- **Court Permission**: Required for withdrawal
- **Non-Compoundable**: Serious crimes cannot be withdrawn
- **Victim Consent**: Required for compounding
- **Court Discretion**: Final decision with court

## Special Courts

### Q: What are fast track courts
596.title: Court Faq - Part 8

597.text:
Special Courts

### Q: What are fast track courts. **A:**
- **Purpose**: Speedy disposal of cases
- **Target**: Dispose cases within 1 year
- **Types**: Criminal, civil, commercial fast track courts
- **Special Rules**: Limited adjournments, daily hearings
- **Cases**: Serious crimes, commercial disputes

### Q: What is Lok Adalat. **A:**
- **Alternative Dispute Resolution**: Settlement outside regular court
- **No Court Fee**: Free of cost
- **Consensual**: Settlement with mutual agreement
- **Binding**: Settlement has force of court decree
- **Types**: Permanent, national, mobile Lok Adalats
597.title: Court Faq - Part 9

598.text:
# Legal Rights and Procedures Guide

Understanding your legal rights and court procedures is essential for navigating the Indian legal system effectively
598.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 1

599.text:
for navigating the Indian legal system effectively. ## Fundamental Rights Under Constitution

### Article 14 - Right to Equality
- **Equal Protection**: All persons equal before law
- **Non-Discrimination**: State cannot discriminate on basis of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth
- **Equal Opportunity**: Equal opportunity in public employment

### Article 19 - Right to Freedom
- **Freedom of Speech**: Expression, assembly, association
- **Freedom of Movement**: Throughout India
- **Freedom of Residence**: Reside and settle anywhere in India
- **Freedom of Profession**: Practice any profession, trade, business

### Article 20 - Protection from Criminal Prosecution
- **Ex-post facto**: No punishment under ex-post facto law
- **Double Jeopardy**: Cannot be prosecuted twice for same offense
- **Self-Incrimination**: Cannot be compelled to be witness against self

### Article 21 - Right to Life and Liberty
- **Due Process**: No person deprived of life/liberty except by due process
- **Fair Trial**: Right to speedy and fair trial
- **Legal Aid**: Right to free legal aid if cannot afford

### Article 22 - Right Against Arbitrary Arrest
- **Grounds of Arrest**: Must be informed of grounds
- **Legal Representation**: Right to consult and be defended by lawyer
- **Magistrate Approval**: Cannot be detained beyond 24 hours without magistrate's order

## Criminal Procedure Rights

### At Time of Arrest
1
599.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 2

600.text:
Criminal Procedure Rights

### At Time of Arrest
1. **Right to Know**: Grounds of arrest must be told
2. **Right to Silence**: Not obliged to answer questions
3. **Right to Lawyer**: Can demand lawyer immediately
4. **Right to Medical**: Medical examination if injured
5. **Right to Inform**: Family/friends must be informed
6. **Right to Bail**: For bailable offenses

### During Investigation
1. **Miranda Rights**: Right to remain silent
2. **No Torture**: Protection from police torture/custodial violence
3. **Medical Exam**: Right to medical examination
4. **Legal Counsel**: Right to meet lawyer privately
5. **Complaint**: Can complain against police misconduct

### During Trial
1. **Presumption of Innocence**: Innocent until proven guilty
2
600.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 3

601.text:
ion of Innocence**: Innocent until proven guilty
2. **Burden of Proof**: On prosecution to prove guilt
3. **Right to Defense**: Present defense, call witnesses
4. **Cross-Examination**: Question prosecution witnesses
5. **Speedy Trial**: Right to conclude trial without unnecessary delay
6. **Public Trial**: Generally open to public
7. **Interpreter**: Right to interpreter if don't understand language

## Civil Procedure Rights

### Filing Civil Cases
1. **Access to Courts**: Right to approach courts for grievances
2. **Legal Representation**: Right to engage lawyer
3. **Court Fees**: Prescribed court fees must be paid
4. **Service of Notice**: Proper service on opposite party
5. **Evidence**: Right to present evidence, call witnesses

### During Civil Trial
1
601.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 4

602.text:
evidence, call witnesses

### During Civil Trial
1. **Fair Hearing**: Right to be heard
2. **Cross-Examination**: Right to cross-examine witnesses
3. **Documentary Evidence**: Right to produce documents
4. **Expert Evidence**: Right to call expert witnesses
5. **Final Arguments**: Right to present final arguments

## Special Procedures for Vulnerable Groups

### Women
1. **Section 154 CrPC**: Right to lodge FIR
2. **Section 164 CrPC**: Statement before magistrate
3. **In-Camera Trial**: For sexual offenses
4. **Female Police**: For recording statement in sexual offenses
5. **Victim Compensation**: Right to compensation
6. **Legal Aid**: Free legal aid available

### Children
1. **Juvenile Justice**: Special juvenile courts
2. **Best Interest**: All decisions in best interest of child
3
602.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 5

603.text:
erest**: All decisions in best interest of child
3. **No Publicity**: Identity cannot be disclosed
4. **Rehabilitation**: Focus on rehabilitation, not punishment
5. **Guardian**: Right to guardian/parent presence
6. **Special Procedures**: Child-friendly court procedures

### Disabled Persons
1. **Reasonable Accommodation**: Court procedures adapted
2. **Sign Language**: Interpreter for hearing impaired
3. **Accessibility**: Physical access to courts
4. **Assistance**: Help in filing cases, understanding procedures
5
603.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 6

604.text:
: Help in filing cases, understanding procedures
5. **Special Courts**: Some states have special courts

## Emergency Procedures

### Habeas Corpus
- **Article 32/226**: Constitutional remedy
- **Purpose**: Challenge illegal detention
- **Courts**: High Court, Supreme Court
- **Immediate**: Can be filed immediately
- **No Limitation**: No limitation period

### Anticipatory Bail
- **Section 438**: CrPC provision
- **Pre-Arrest**: Before actual arrest
- **Courts**: Sessions Court, High Court
- **Conditions**: Subject to conditions
- **Protection**: Protection from arrest if conditions followed

### Stay Orders
- **Urgent Cases**: In urgent matters
- **Interim Relief**: Till final disposal
- **Higher Courts**: Can grant stay on lower court orders
- **Conditions**: Usually subject to conditions
- **Security**: May require security deposit

## Consumer Rights

### Consumer Protection Act 2019
1
604.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 7

605.text:
onsumer Rights

### Consumer Protection Act 2019
1. **Right to Safety**: Protection from hazardous goods/services
2. **Right to Information**: About quality, quantity, price
3. **Right to Choose**: Access to variety of goods at competitive prices
4. **Right to be Heard**: Voice in consumer policy decisions
5. **Right to Redressal**: Compensation for unfair trade practices
6. **Right to Education**: Consumer awareness and education

### Consumer Courts
- **District Commission**: Up to Rs. 1 crore
- **State Commission**: Rs. 1 crore to Rs. 10 crore  
- **National Commission**: Above Rs. 10 crore
- **Simple Procedure**: Less formal than regular courts
- **No Court Fee**: On complaint, only on appeal

## Information Rights

### Right to Information Act 2005
1
605.title: Rights And Procedures - Part 8

606.text:
mation Rights

### Right to Information Act 2005
1. **Access to Information**: Right to seek information from public authorities
2. **Time Bound**: Information within 30 days
3. **Fees**: Minimal fees for information
4. **Appeals**: Two levels of appeals
5. **Penalties**: For non-compliance by authorities
6. **Exemptions**: Certain categories exempted

## Legal Aid and Support

### Legal Services Authorities
1. **Free Legal Aid**: For poor and marginalized
2. **Eligibility**: Income below prescribed limit
3. **Services**: Free lawyer, court fees waiver
4. **Lok Adalats**: Alternative dispute resolution
5. **Legal Literacy**: Awareness programs

### How to Access Legal Aid
1. **Application**: To District Legal Services Authority
2. **Documents**: Income certificate, ID proof

y
2. **Documents**: Income certificate, ID proof
3. **Automatic**: For certain categories (women, children, disabled, SC/ST)
4. **Court Appointment**: Court can appoint lawyer
5. **NGOs**: Various organizations provide free legal aid

## Documentation and Records

### Important Documents to Maintain
1. **FIR Copy**: In criminal cases
2. **Charge Sheet**: When filed
3. **Bail Orders**: All bail-related orders
4. **Court Orders**: All interim orders
5. **Evidence**: Photos, medical reports, documents
6. **Witness Details**: Names, addresses, statements

### Court Records
1. **Case Diary**: Daily proceedings record
2. **Order Sheets**: All orders passed

4. **Certified Copies**: Official copies from court
5. **Appeal Papers**: If appealing decision
